                                                                                                                          British sea-weeds. Drawn from Professor Harvey's "Phycologia britannica."
                                                                                                                          With descriptions, an amateur's synopsis, rules for laying out sea-weeds,
                                                                                                                          an order for arranging them in the herbarium, and an appendix
                                                                                                                          of new species. By Mrs. Alfred Gatty.
                                                                                                                          Gatty, Alfred, Mrs., 1809-1873.
                                                                                                                          London, Bell and Daldy, 1872.

                                                                                                                                BRITISH SEA-WEEDS.
                                                                                                                                                                        DRAWN FROM
                                                                                                                          PROFESSOR                      HARVEY’S “PHYCOLOGIA BRITANNICA.”
                                                                                                                                                                 WITH    DESCRIPTIONS,
                                                                                                                              AN AMATEUR/S SYNOPSIS,                 RULES FOR LAYING OUT SEA-WEEDS,
                                                                                                                                  AN ORDER               FOR.   ARRANGING THEM IN THE HERBARIUM,
                                                                                                                                              AND AN APPENDIX OF NEW                      SPECIES.

                                                                                                                               Figs.      173        &   174.         NITOPHYLLUM PUNCTATUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Bright pink.
                                                                                                                          Substmwe.           Delicately          membranaceous.
                                                                                                                          Character       of Frond.     A thin, <U+FB02>at, ribless expansion; xmstalked (sessile);
                                                                                                                                    irregular  in outline, but always inclined to wedge-shaped; variously slit
                                                                                                                                    and  divided.    Sometimes   nearly simple, with afew forked (cliehotomous)
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:03 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    divisions (laciniae) above; or fringing the margins also.        Sometimes
                                                                                                                                    narrow, and repeatedly forked from the base.         (See Fig. 174; upper
                                                                                                                                    form.)    Glossy when dried.      Unmarked by veiny lines.
                                                                                                                          Jfcasurnmcnt.                      4~
                                                                                                                                             From to 12 inches long, and about                as broad.   At   Cushendall,
                                                                                                                                    N. Ireland,  feet long by
                                                                                                                                                         5       wide.         3
                                                                                                                          Fr1u:fi<U+FB01>caifion. Of two kinds.    Clustered spores in small, globose, capsules;
                                                                                                                                                                          1.
                                                                                                                                  immersed in, and thickly scattered over, the surface.    2. Tetraspores
                                                                                                                                    in large more or less oval groups (sari), scattered, or con<U+FB01>ned                   to a
                                                                                                                                    central portion.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.   Several stations on our coasts. West of Scotland.     Finest in
                                                                                                                                  Ireland. Attached to algae in pools at low-water mark, and in deeper
                                                                                                                                    water.
                                                                                                                                         Dr. Harvey has here collected under one name several plants which have been
                                                                                                                                      accounted             but which he has satis<U+FB01>ed himself a ee in certain important
                                                                                                                                                     aracters. Amateurs may be guided by the <U+FB02>ight, light, pink colour,
                                                                                                                                      distinctive splecies,
                                                                                                                                                     c
                                                                                                                                      extremely thin substance, glossiness when dry, and entire absence of veiny lines,
                                                                                                                                      to  a recognition of this plant under its many forms.

                                                                                                                                              Fig.      175.      NITOPHYLLUM HILLIZE.
                                                                                                                           Colour.      A     <U+FB01>ne-r0se-rod,      which       turns   to orange in fresh water.
                                                                                                                           Substance.         Membranaeeous          and     tender, but thickish.             Mrs. Gri<U+FB02>iths said,
                                                                                                                                     “resembling soft kid-leather.”
                                                                                                                           Character of Frond. A <U+FB02>at, ribless expansion;      rising from a short stalk; of
                                                                                                                                  round but irregular outline; more or        less deeply slit into oblong,
                                                                                                                                     broad, rounded divisions (larinize). Margins smooth and even; or
                                                                                                                                     occasionally slightly waved. Obscure veins rising from the base, and
                                                                                                                                     sometimes spreading faintly upwards.
                                                                                                                           Jfcasurement.         From 4 to        8 inches      long.
                                                                                                                           Fructt<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds. 1. Clustered spores in large globose capsules;
                                                                                                                                   immersed in, and scattered over, the surface.          2. Tetraspores in
                                                                                                                                   extremely minute, dot-like groups (s0ri), scattered over the upper part
                                                                                                                                     of the divisions          (lacinice).
                                                                                                                           Ilabitat.        South of      England.        On the shady sides of deep tidal-pools                  near
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:03 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                     low-water       mark.      Rare.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.     176.        NITOPHYLLUM GMELINI.
                                                                                                                           Colour.      Purplish-red.
                                                                                                                           Substance.         Membranaceous;         but crisp and somewhat rigid when <U+FB01>rst gathered.
                                                                                                                           Character of Frond.    A <U+FB02>at, ribless expansion, rising from a short stalk; of
                                                                                                                                  broadly fan-shaped or round outline; more or less deeply slit and
                                                                                                                                  divided.  Divisions (laciniw) broadly wedge-shaped, waved or curled.
                                                                                                                                  Margins  smooth   and even. Obscure veins rising from the base and
                                                                                                                                     sometimes spreading            faintly upwards.
                                                                                                                           lfeasurement.         From      2   to 4 inches       high, and         as   wide   or   wider.   In Irish
                                                                                                                                     specimens 6 inches.
                                                                                                                           Fructmyicat-ion.        Of     two    kinds.        1. Clustered          spores  in largish, globose

                                                                                                                                     capsules;       scattered over the surface.              2.    Tctraspores in long, line-like

                                                                                                                                                                             PLATE      XXXIX.
                                                                                                                                          Fig.    177.            NITOPHYLLUM LACERATUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.         Dull-purplish, or brownish-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Membranaceous.               Extremely thin; cracking               when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character        of Frond.        A <U+FB02>at, ribless                   (sessile);
                                                                                                                                                                                    expansion;          much slit and
                                                                                                                                                                                                         unstalked
                                                                                                                                     divided     in   a forked                      The divisions (laciniw) sometimes
                                                                                                                                                                    manner (dicbotomously).
                                                                                                                                     narrow, like those of the narrow variety of N. punctatum (see Plate XXXVIII.
                                                                                                                                     Fig. 174, the upper form); sometimes as broad as those of N. Gmelini (Plate
                                                                                                                                     XXXVIII. Fig. 176); generally obtuse; margins either smooth and even or
                                                                                                                                     cnrled; or fringed with small leafy frondlets.   Distinctly marked veins rising
                                                                                                                                     from the base          and spreading          upwards.
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurement.         From       2     to 10 inches long.
                                                                                                                          F’rzwt1-7<U+FB01>cation.      Of     two       kinds.      1.   Clustered        spores    in globose capsules;               scattered.
                                                                                                                                     2.   Tetraspores       in oblong groups          (sari) disposed along the margin,                      or     in the
                                                                                                                                     fringing lea<U+FB02>ets.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our coasts generally.              Near low-water             mark.    Common.
                                                                                                                                          The only Nitophyllum which re<U+FB02>ects prismatic colours in the water. A variety
                                                                                                                                        has all the tips of the divisions turned in like hooks, and cling by them to
                                                                                                                                        the small algae near. For other Nitophytbume see Plate XL. Figs. 181 and 185.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.       178.          PLOOLAMIUM                               COCOINEUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.         Bright pink-red; particularly after                  a    short    exposure.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Elastic, though thin; not easily tearing.                        Giving out       a pleasant         scent in
                                                                                                                                     fresh water.
                                                                                                                          C/zaraoter     of Frond. Flat, or nearly so; very narrow; tufted;                                   excessively        branched.
                                                                                                                                     Main stems irregularly divided; thickly set with alternate,                               spreading         branches,
                                                                                                                                     which    are furnished    throughout with short-curved,                                  pointed       branchlets.
                                                                                                                                     Branchlets  simple, or furnished on their inner face with a                              smaller    set of short
                                                                                                                                     curved, pointed branchlets, arranged four in succession;                                 these sometimes           re
                                                                                                                                     branchleted       in     a   similar manner;         the compound            branchlets      resembling         little
                                                                                                                                     combs.      All    the frond          at one level as         if   cut out of paper.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Measurement.           From 2 to           12    inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         Of     two       kinds; external.        1.   A        mass of      minute     spores      in    globosc
                                                                                                                                     capsules, unstalked;           borne on the edge of the upper branches.                         2. Tetrasjaores
                                                                                                                                     in minute,       simple,      or branched       Stichidia;          on the branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.        Our coasts generally.               On rocks and the larger                 alga, at low-water             mark,
                                                                                                                                     or beyond.         Common         and abundant.

                                                                                                                                        Fig.       179.      RHODYMENIA                           LACINIATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      The <U+FB01>nest crimson.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Thickish; soft    ; elastic      though   membranaceous.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond.     A            expansion; rising from a short <U+FB02>at stem; of more
                                                                                                                                                           <U+FB02>at ribless
                                                                                                                                    or less   fan-shapedoutline; deeply slit and divided in a forked manner (dicho
                                                                                                                                    tomously).   Divisions (laciniw) wedge-shaped; re-divided in the same way; the
                                                                                                                                    tips obtuse; often torn.   When in frueti<U+FB01>cation the margins curled or fringed
                                                                                                                                    with minute leafy frondlets; these occasionally found on the surface.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.       From   3    to 10 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fmcti<U+FB01>cation.        Of two kinds.          1.    A    mass of minute    spores in globose capsules, im
                                                                                                                                    mersed in the fringing or surface lea<U+FB02>ets.                2. Tetraspores        forming cloudy spots
                                                                                                                                    on the surface;       or along    the margins,      which     are then smooth            and entire.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Our coasts generally.              On reeks and stones, &c. in the            sea;    rarely    within
                                                                                                                                    tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                                                 Now Callophyllie         laciniata.

                                                                                                                                         Fig.      180.       RHODYMENIA                           PALMETTA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Rose-red;    darker   when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Menibranaceous,      except the stems, which            are   elastic.
                                                                                                                          C'haractor    of Frond. A <U+FB01>at, ribless, fan-shaped, but often repeatedly forked expansion,
                                                                                                                                    rising from a longish, <U+FB01>rst cylindrical, then compressed stem, which is either
                                                                                                                                    simple or divided; widening gradually upwards.     Tufted. Divisions (laciniw)
                                                                                                                                    narrow, with rounded spaces between, and very smooth, <U+FB02>at margins.         Root,
                                                                                                                                    a broad    disc, sometimes        accompanied      by <U+FB01>bres.
                                                                                                                          Jlfcasurement.       Stems from         inch to 2 inches long.           Fronds      1 or 2 inches.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>oation.       Of two kinds.                 A
                                                                                                                                                                    mass of minute spores in glohose prominent
                                                                                                                                                                       1.
                                                                                                                                    capsules, seated on the edges  of the margins, or scattered; generally towards
                                                                                                                                    the tips of the lacinim. 2. Tctraspores forming deep red groups (sort) in the
                                                                                                                                    expanded tips.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Habilut.       Our shores generally,         but inclining southwards.             On rocks,         &e. near     the
                                                                                                                                    verge of low-water       mark,       and lower.     Not   uncommon.
                                                                                                                                        Varying greatly in           general appearance; but usually tolerably fan-shaped.
                                                                                                                                      Sometimes with only a           short stein, sometimes with almost none; or sometimes
                                                                                                                                      merely forked into two          narrow leaves. (See           Its pink-colour, crisp, yet
                                                                                                                                      delicate substance, and         fructi<U+FB01>cation, must be<U+FB01>gure.)

                                                                                                                                                                       PLATE      XL.
                                                                                                                                      Fig.       181.         NITOPHYLLUM VERSICOLOR.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    When fresh, rose-red; turning to a beautiful golden orange in fresh water;
                                                                                                                                 even when wetted by a shower only.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Thick; membranaceous; soft; all but the stems, which are <U+FB01>rmly elastic.
                                                                                                                          Character of Fro/ul.    A <U+FB02>at, ribless expansion, spreading suddenly from the top of a
                                                                                                                                 somewhat tuberous stem.       General outline round.    Slit into several deeply-cut,
                                                                                                                                 wedge-shaped divisions.    Divisions (laciniw) subdivided; many times slit above;
                                                                                                                                 their tips rounded, and generally thickened with hard, wart-like lumps. Margins
                                                                                                                                 smooth; or sometimes fringed with minute hair-like frondlets.         Uumarked by
                                                                                                                                 veiny lines.   Root unknown.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.  From 1 to 3 inches ‘high and across.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation.   Unknown.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Ilfracombe.   Youghal. Thrown ashore from                 deep   water.     Very rare.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.      182.        DELESSERIA RUSCIFOLIA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A     clear crimson,
                                                                                                                                                          rather than pink.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Delicately membranaceous, but somewhat <U+FB01>rmer than D. hypoglossum.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froud.        Like that of D. h_1/po_qlossum, composed entirely of leaves growing
                                                                                                                                   from leaves; the younger from the midribs of the older.         But in D. ru->-czjolia,
                                                                                                                                   the leaves are oblong with obtuse tips; and do not taper at the base.
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurem-ent.     Seldom more than 2 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation. Of two kinds.          1. A mass of spores in globose capsules;       imbcdded
                                                                                                                                   in, but prominent upon, the midribs of the leaves.         2. Tctruspores in groups
                                                                                                                                    (sort), forming oblong lines on each side the midribs.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.          On rocks near low-water mark; or occasionally on
                                                                                                                                    algae.     Not   common.
                                                                                                                             For other Delesserias refer back to Plate          XXYIII.   Fig.   150, and    Plate   XXXVII.
                                                                                                                                               Fig.     183.      RHODYMENIA BIFIDA;
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A  delicate rose-red or pink; sometimes dingy.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Delicately membrauaceous; generally transparent.
                                                                                                                          C/zaracter of Frond.       A <U+FB02>at, ribless expansion, deeply and repeatedly divided from
                                                                                                                                   the base. General outline round. Divisions (laciniza) ribbon-like or wedge-shaped;
                                                                                                                                   many times forked (dichotomous);      their omits rounded.     Margins sometimes
                                                                                                                                   smooth (entire); sometimes fringed with minute, leafy, or hair-like frondlets;
                                                                                                                                   tips blunt or rounded.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.     From 3 to 10 inches long.     Width varying.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.      Of  two  kinds.   1. A mass  of spores in globose capsules; external;
                                                                                                                                   seated (sessile) on the margins; or rarely over the surface of the upper divisions.
                                                                                                                                   2. Tetraspores forming cloudy spots in the upper divisions.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.             On rocks   and algae at low-water       mark,    or   beyond.
                                                                                                                                 Frequent.
                                                                                                                             Now Rhodopliyllis         bl<U+FB01>da..   The marginal   capsules are a great clue to this plant.

                                                                                                                                           Fig.    184.            RHODYMENIA                         CRISTATA.
                                                                                                                          Colou/r.     A   rose-red;    becoming       scarlet in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Membranaceous.
                                                                                                                                                             \
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.            lalat; narrow;       repeatedly divided in a forked manner
                                                                                                                                                                                  ribless;
                                                                                                                                 from the base.              General   fan-shaped or round (the <U+FB01>gure fails to give
                                                                                                                                                                        outline
                                                                                                                                     this.)    Divisions widening upwards;    many times sub-divided;     lesser ones
                                                                                                                                     alternate, occasionally jagged at the ends.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.        British specimens rarely above an inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructl/ication.      Of two kinds. 1. A mass of spores in little spherical dark-red
                                                                                                                                     capsules, half the size of poppy-seed; imbedded in the upper margins.  2.
                                                                                                                                     Tetraspcres imbedded in the thickened and darkened tips.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Orkney and Shetland    Islands.                Frith of Forth. Berwick-upon-Tweed, and
                                                                                                                                     a few more   places in the north.                Thrown ashore; sometimes on the stems of
                                                                                                                                     Lam. digitata.   Very rare indeed.
                                                                                                                                     Now Euthora cristata.             Six specimens were found at Berwick in              1853.
                                                                                                                               Fig.         185.        NITOPHYLLUM BONNEMAISONIA.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Bright rose-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Delicately membranaceous.                 Very thin.

                                                                                                                                   wedge-shaped; about equal in length; overlapping     each other.   Veins rising
                                                                                                                                   from the base, and spreading faintly upwazds.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.   From 2 to 4 inches high, and about as broad.
                                                                                                                                                                 1. A mass of
                                                                                                                                                                       -~

                                                                                                                                           Fig.        186.         GRATELOUPIA FILIOINA.

                                                                                                                                 or alternate, wide-spreading, wavy, <U+FB02>at branches.   Branches  either simple or
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                 clothed in the upper part with branchlets;   all tapering to each end.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.         British specimens seldom more than 2 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.       Of two kinds.             1. Spares in minute globular capsules; immersed in
                                                                                                                                     the substance      of       the branches.   2. Tetraspores imbedded in the branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      South of England.    On submarine rocks at half-tide                   level;   frequently       whcre
                                                                                                                                     a small strcamlet runs into the sea. Very rare.
                                                                                                                                            Very like    some       forms of Gelidiam. corneum;          but much softer.

                                                                                                                                              Fig.      187.         RHODYMENIA                           CILIATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A     deep,    full, more or     less     bright red; becoming      darker      in drying.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Thick;     <U+FB01>rm; elastic; quite crisp when fresh.
                                                                                                                          Cliaracter of Frond.      A <U+FB02>at, ribless, leafy expansion; rising from a very short stalk;
                                                                                                                                    more or less broadly lanceolate, or once forked.     Margins toothed; or fringed
                                                                                                                                    with small, hair-like frondlets, some of which expand into leafy, lanceolate, or
                                                                                                                                    once-forked formations like the <U+FB01>rst; while in others, both on the margin and
                                                                                                                                    surface, the capsular           fruit is formed.       Root <U+FB01>brous.        Fruiting        in winter.
                                                                                                                          Meamrment.             From     2 to 8 inches        long; width of leaves varying from              Q, to 1§ inches!
                                                                                                                          Fructification.   Of two kinds.               1.     A   mass of spores in      globose capsules, formed             in
                                                                                                                                  the hair-like frondlets.             2. Tetraspores        forming cloud-like patches;              dispersed
                                                                                                                                    over the surface.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Our shores generally,             except the extreme north-east.              At Bridlington, but
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    not at Filey.         On rocks,         &c. near low-water mark,          and beyond.          Frequent.
                                                                                                                                                                        -~
                                                                                                                                        Now Calliblephm-is ciliata. The tips of the hair-like frondlets in which the
                                                                                                                                               form are turned aside by the swelling, and project sideways, like the
                                                                                                                                      bil of a bird. (See <U+FB01>gure.)
                                                                                                                                      capsules
                                                                                                                                                Fig.     188.        RHODYMENIA JUBATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A     dull purplish, or pinkish-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Thick;    soft; elastic; limp.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond.         A   <U+FB01>at, ribless, leafy expansion; rising from a cylindrical stem;
                                                                                                                                    narrow-lanceolate;         tapering   to the base; branched with leafy formations of the
                                                                                                                                    same     character;       or   sometimes with thread-shaped,    <U+FB01>bre-like tendrils which
                                                                                                                                    spring      both from the surface and margins; fringed (like R. ciliata) with lesser
                                                                                                                                    hair-like frondlets, in which the fruit of both kinds is produced.     Root <U+FB01>brous.
                                                                                                                                    Fruiting in summer.
                                                                                                                          llleaau/rement.        From     1 to     8 inches      long.   Width varying almost incredibly.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         Of    two kinds.      1.    A     mass of spores in hemi-spherical            capsules, seated
                                                                                                                                    (sessile)    on the fringing frondlets.              2. Tetraspores    immersed        in the    same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      South        and west coasts.          On the bottoms of tide-pools           between tide-marks;
                                                                                                                                    chie<U+FB02>y      near low-water       mark      or among the roots of          L.   digitata.     Frequent.
                                                                                                                                        So various in width and size that it is very difficult to describe.                         Sometimes
                                                                                                                                      “<U+FB01>liform and entangled," and resembling Gigartina acicularis.

                                                                                                                                  Figs.       189   & 190.        RHODYMENIA                   PALMATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A dull purplish, or brownish-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        When young, membranaceons;            afterwards   leathery.
                                                                                                                          Character of Freud. A <U+FB01>at, ribless, broadly wedge-shaped expansion, much
                                                                                                                                 and irregularly divided into numerous, jagged, branching divisions;
                                                                                                                                    or else repeatedly branched   in a forked manner (dichotomouslg/).
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    Margins smooth (entire), or fringed with leaf-like formations. Root
                                                                                                                                    a disc.
                                                                                                                          llleasuremcnt.        From   2    to 20 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fmcti<U+FB01>cution.         Only one kind known.        Tetraspores forming cloud-like patches;
                                                                                                                                    dispersed     over the surface.
                                                                                                                          Ila-bitat.   Our coasts everywhere.           On rocks and the stems of Lam. dig-itafa,
                                                                                                                                    &c. Very common.
                                                                                                                                          Fig. 189 represents the commonest form. In Fig. 190 we have, in the nar
                                                                                                                                       rower speeimen, Var. B. Sarmlcnsis;      in tho broader, Var. y. sobollfera.   And
                                                                                                                                       many intermediate varieties occur.      Dr. Harvey assures us, that once seen and
                                                                                                                                       tasted, no one can fail to recognise R. palmata again.     It is the Dulec of the
                                                                                                                                       Scotch; the Dillisk of the Irish; and is eaten either raw or cooked, in many
                                                                                                                                       places, by the country             At Miltown Malbay (W. Ireland), and elsewhere,
                                                                                                                                       they boil or stew it wit geople.
                                                                                                                                                                  a little dripping or butter, and pepper, into a savoury
                                                                                                                                       mess, like stewed cabbage.

                                                                                                                                                                            PLATE          XLII.
                                                                                                                             Fig.        191.         SPHZEROCOCCUS                                  CORONOPIFOLIUS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   <U+FB01>ne scarlet-red;     darker        in the main stems.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Gristly; the stems very strong;                horny when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character       of Frond.          Compressed;         narrow; very much            branched;      wide-spreading,
                                                                                                                                    forming      a rounded      outline.        Main stems thickened          in     the centre;    repeatedly
                                                                                                                                    divided,     with    a   mixture       of    forked     (diclwtomous) and alternate branching.
                                                                                                                                    Branches      several    times re-branched            in the same irregular way; the margins
                                                                                                                                    of the upper ones generally fringed with minute, short, stalk-like, horizontally
                                                                                                                                    set frondlets, in some of which the capsular fruit is formed.    Last branchlets
                                                                                                                                    much and closely divided; spreading; with acute tips.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.        From 6 to 12 inches long, or more.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         Only one kind known.              A      mass of spores in globose   capsules, formed
                                                                                                                                    in the fringing frondlets;             the swelling      turning the tips aside as in Rbod-ymenia
                                                                                                                                    ciliata.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Southern and western                    shores of Great           Britain and      Ireland.     Niton    Bay,
                                                                                                                                 Isle of Wight, abundant.                   Isle of Man.            Isle of Bute.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.     192.        GELIDIUM CARTILAGINEUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   <U+FB01>ne dark-purple;       becoming         scarlet,      orange, yellow,     and   <U+FB01>nally greenish
                                                                                                                                    on    exposure.

                                                                                                                          Character       of Frond.  Tufts of very long, narrow, even stems; fnmished with long,
                                                                                                                                    narrow,  regularly altemate branches; these re-branched with a second series;
                                                                                                                                    these again with a third; the series diminishing gradually in length; all at
                                                                                                                                    one level, like the plumes of a feather (pinnate); each branch lanceolatc in
                                                                                                                                    general outline.   Root <U+FB01>brous.
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>feasu/rement.         From 12 to 18 inches long.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Fructz<U+FB01>cation.         Only one kind known.                A     mass  of spores in oval capsules, imbedded
                                                                                                                                  in the        centre of the last         branchlets,      their tips protruding beyond.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.        Found on the shore at Freshwater                        Bay; also at Ryde, but not          a    native

                                                                                                                                       Fig.       193.         GRACILARIA COMPRESSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A   transparent       dull red; becoming brighter in fresh water.

                                                                                                                                    long, and mostly simple;             tapering to a <U+FB01>ne point; occasionally furnished

                                                                                                                                  sules;      external;        sessile   on    the branches.    2. Tctraspores minute;
                                                                                                                                    imbedded in the same.
                                                                                                                          Iiabitat.     South     of England.            Cast ashore from deep               water.          Very rare.

                                                                                                                                                                           PLATE            XLIII.
                                                                                                                              Fig.            194.          CYSTOCLONIUM                               PURPURASOENS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A    dull, purplish-red;     becoming redder in fresh water;               pinky towards        the tips.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          When fresh, thick; <U+FB02>eshy; semi-transparent                       and very brittle.       When dry,
                                                                                                                                    becoming     tough, and shrinking considerably.
                                                                                                                          Character        of Frond.        Thread-shaped   (<U+FB01>liform), long, bushy, excessively branched.
                                                                                                                                    Stem       generally    undivided; bearing long alternate spreading branches tapering
                                                                                                                                    to     each end.        Branches  either simple or forked, bearing a second and third
                                                                                                                                    set of similar character.             Branchlets         many      times    divided      (almost in tufts),
                                                                                                                                    scattered        both   on stem and branches;              with very acute tips.            Root <U+FB01>brous.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.            From 6 inches to         2    feet long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.             Of two kinds.        1.    A    mass of spores in globose capsules;                formed   in
                                                                                                                                    the branchlets;          swelling     them       out.     2. Tetraspores       imbedded       in the     lesser
                                                                                                                                    branches.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our coasts       generally.         On rocks,      stones, and algae.          Between      tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                    Very common.
                                                                                                                                                  will do well to accustom themselves to the new name of this plant,
                                                                                                                                           Collectors
                                                                                                                                                                          mi
                                                                                                                                                   pmpurascens, as Dr. Harvey has no hesitation in declaring that it
                                                                                                                                         Cg/stoclonium
                                                                                                                                      was erroneously placed among the Hypncas.    The name Hypnca is accordingly
                                                                                                                                      dropped altogether.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.            196.        GRACILARIA MULTIPARTITA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.         A   dull purplish-red; becoming redder in fresh water; pinky towards the tips.
                                                                                                                          Substance.           When fresh, thick; <U+FB02>eshy; semi-transparent                      and very brittle.       When dry,
                                                                                                                                    becoming       tough, and shrinking considerably.
                                                                                                                          Character          of Frond.      Flat; narrow;            repeatedly       but irregularly forked or divided,
                                                                                                                                    from the base; at one level, as                   if   cut out.     Divisions (laoiniw) narrow-wedge
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    shape;        their tips acute.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurcment.             From   41   to 12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.             Of two      kinds.    1.    A    mass     of spores       in conical,      very    prominent
                                                                                                                                    capsules; external; sessile on the surface of the frond-divisions.                            2. Tetraspores
                                                                                                                                    imbedded in the same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.           South    coast of England.             On rocks,     &c. in deep       water.      Very rare.

                                                                                                                                         Fig.     197.        GIGARTINA PISTILLATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Aedull purple, becoming darker in drying.
                                                                                                                          Substazwe.         Gristly when fresh; horny when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Froml.           Compressed,       simple,  narrow-wedge-shaped    stems,
                                                                                                                                     spreading into branches right and left above,             in a repeatedly forked
                                                                                                                                     manner (I.ll<:lto-f077l0lLSl--l/)§ forming a broadly fan-shaped outline.  Angles
                                                                                                                                     of branching (rueils) wide and rounded; tips acute.    Branches naked,
                                                                                                                                     or clothed with short horizontal, simple or forked branchlets, on which
                                                                                                                                     the capsular fruit is borne.                Fruiting in winter.
                                                                                                                          illeasurevnem‘.        From    3   to 6 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructification.     Of two kinds.    1. A mass of spores in large spherical capsules,
                                                                                                                                     depressed in the centre; no darker than the frond; external; sessile
                                                                                                                                     on the branchlets, either singly or in pairs.    2. Tet:-aspores in groups
                                                                                                                                     (s0ri) immersed  in the  branches;  distorting  them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.       Coast of Cornwall.             Jersey.       On rocks near low-water mark.        Very
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                     rare.
