                                                                                                                                     Fig.     198.        GRAOILARIA OONFERVOIDES.
                                                                                                                                 0
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A    pale or deep        red;    becoming       paler in decay.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Rigid;     gristly;    not adhering         to paper.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froml. Long; thread-shaped (/il:lform); solid; irregularly (often
                                                                                                                                 very slightly) branched. Branches long and simple, or here and there
                                                                                                                                 forked; either naked, or furnished with a few short branchlets.
                                                                                                                                     Brauchlets       tapering     to each end.
                                                                                                                          Illeasurement.         From     3 to 20 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         Of two kinds.              1.    A   mass of spores in globose capsules;
                                                                                                                                     external;    sessile on the branches;             abundant.   2. Tetraspores; minute;
                                                                                                                                     imbedded in the same.                              ~
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Ilabilat.      Our shores generally. On rocks and stones in the                    sea near low
                                                                                                                                     water mark.   Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                         Varying very much in length and the amount of branching.     Var. B. procerrima-
                                                                                                                                      has its branches “very long, generally simple, and almost naked."   Var. . a-lbida-
                                                                                                                                      is compressed instead of thread-shaped, and several times forked, with awl-shaped
                                                                                                                                      branchlcts.   Var. 5. geniculatu. is distorted and bent, as if broken, where the
                                                                                                                                      capsules occur.

                                                                                                                                                                              PLATE       XLIV.
                                                                                                                                                Fig.     199.           GELIDIUM OORNEUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dull purplish-red,       becoming        pink and yellow on exposure, or in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Between    gristly and horny; polished.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Flat or thread-shaped (<U+FB01>li<U+FB01>arm), very narzow, still‘; formally
                                                                                                                                  branched; the whole at one level, as if cut out.  Stems one width throughout;
                                                                                                                                 alternately branched; set with short, simple, wide-spread branchlets.  Branches
                                                                                                                                 tapering to both ends; re-branched once or twice, exactly in the same manner
                                                                                                                                 as the stems.     Branchlets  mostly opposite, almost horizontally set, always
                                                                                                                                 tapering to the base; blunt at the tips, in which the capsular fruit is formed.
                                                                                                                          Jllcasurement.        From     1 to      8   inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds.                 1.   A    mass of spores in oval capsules, formed               in the
                                                                                                                                 tips of the branchlets.                2.    Tctraspores  immersed in the same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally, but shy of the north-east, except the slender, thread
                                                                                                                                 like variety, G. erinalc. On rocks between tide-marks.   Very common.
                                                                                                                                                         GYMNOGONGRUS GRIFFITHSIZE.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                Fig.         200.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   dull purplish-red,        fading     to yellow   on exposure.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Gristly when fresh; horny when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Entangled tufts of slender, wiry threads; repeatedly forked
                                                                                                                                 (dichotomous);   the tips of one length; forming a round outline.     Branches
                                                                                                                                 wavy; of one thickness throughout.      Angles of branching  (axils) wide and
                                                                                                                                 rounded.    Divisions often much crowded above.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.   From 2 to 4 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.   Only one kind known.     Tetraspores forming oblong, wart-like swel
                                                                                                                                  lings, which by degrees surround the stem.    (See <U+FB01>gure.)
                                                                                                                          Hzzbitat.   Devonshire. Bantry Bay. Orkney. Isle of Man. On rocks near low
                                                                                                                                    water mark.         Not       very common.
                                                                                                                                                 For another G5/mnogongrus                see Plate   XLVI.   Fig.   211.
                                                                                                                                                  Fig.       201.            GIGARTINA TEEDII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Purplish; brighter in fresh water; fading to purplish-pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Membranaceous,  but <U+FB01>rm; limp when fresh; horny when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froml.    Flat; narrow; formally branched; at one level, as if cut out
                                                                                                                                                Stems either simple or once forked; set with long, horizontally
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                 (dictichous).
                                                                                                                                 spread branches, tapering to each end, <U+FB01>nely pointed; once or twice re-branched
                                                                                                                                 in the same way. Branchlets slender, tapering; the ends often very much
                                                                                                                                 drawn out; last set short, thorn-like; <U+FB01>nely pointed; horizontal.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.        From     2   to    5 inches       long.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation.         A   mass     of spores     in globose capsules;          sessile    on     the   last   set of
                                                                                                                                    branchlets.        Tetraspores       immersed in the same.
                                                                                                                          Hzzbitat.       Elberry Cove, Torbay.
                                                                                                                                    13

                                                                                                                                           Fig.   202.      CHONDRUS                CRISPUS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Lurid purple in deep water, giving out rainbow-tints; greenish or yellowish
                                                                                                                                   in shallow pools near high-water mark; fading to actual white.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Thickish and <U+FB01>rmly elastic; horny when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.        Flat; repeatedly forked (dichotomous); spreading from a stem
                                                                                                                                   which is taper at base; narrow-wedge shape upwards.         Outline fan-shaped or
                                                                                                                                   round.    Divisions wedge-shaped; <U+FB02>at or curled; sometimes very narrow; some
                                                                                                                                   times very wide; often profuse and spreading; overlapping each other; angles
                                                                                                                                   of branching     (axils), rounded; tips obtuse, and commonly forked.       Margins
                                                                                                                                   sometimes fringed with frondlets.      Root a disc.
                                                                                                                          Jllcasurement.     From 2 to 10 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi/ication.     Of three kinds.      1. Masses of minute    spores in prominent, oval
                                                                                                                                   capsules;   immersed in the lesser frond-divisions.      Rare.   2. Tetraspores  in
                                                                                                                                 large oval groups (sori), scattered all over the surface; often prominent to one
                                                                                                                                 side only.   Common.     3. Prominent warts, composed of radiating       threads;
                                                                                                                                 imperfectly understood.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. All our rocky coasts. Finest in deep water. Very common.
                                                                                                                                       So variable in appearance that no description will suit all the forms.  This
                                                                                                                                    is the plant sold as “Carrigeen," or Irish Moss. When boiled down to a jelly
                                                                                                                                    it is good for coughs and general weakness; excellent also for fattening cattle.
                                                                                                                                    It contains a large per-oentage of nitrogen.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                       Fig.   203.       CHONDRUS              NORVEGICUS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A deep, dull blood-red; or morone.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Firm and elastic; thinner than in Chondrus crispus.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Flat; narrow; repeatedly forked (dichotomous); spreading from
                                                                                                                                   a short cylindrical stem.   Outline fan-shaped or round.    Divisions widening a
                                                                                                                                   little, but not much, upwards; angles of branching (0-mils) wide-spread; tips
                                                                                                                                   rounded.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.      From 2 to 3 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>catfon.      Of two kinds.   1. Minute spores in tiny capsules, imbedded in the
                                                                                                                                   substance of the frond, slightly prominent    to both surfaces.    2. Telraspores
                                                                                                                                   collected into round groups (sari); scattered on both surfaces, prominent.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. The warmer southern and western stations on our coasts. On rocks near
                                                                                                                                   low-water    mark.   Fine at Miltown Malbay.       Saltcoats;  Dr. Lansborongh.
                                                                                                                                   Rather rare.
                                                                                                                                      Now Gymnogongrue Nurvegicus.      Preferring warm to cold latitudes;     so that
                                                                                                                                    the name is an unlucky one.
                                                                                                                                          Fig.    204.     CATENELLA OPUNTIA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dark, dull purple.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Membranaceous.     Tender and soft; more or less full of moisture.
                                                                                                                          Character of    Frond.   Densely tufted; rising from creeping <U+FB01>bres; semi-tubular;     con
                                                                                                                                  stricted at intervals, as if jointed; resembling the Indian <U+FB01>g (Cactus Opuntia)
                                                                                                                                  in miniature; irregularly branched from the constrictions.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.     From § to an inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.    Of two kinds.      1. Masses of spores in broadly-oval  capsules, formed
                                                                                                                                  in one of the lesser branchlets.      2. Tetraspores immersed in the same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.        On rocks near high-water mark.     Common.

                                                                                                                                                                       PLATE    XLV.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.    205.      PHYLLOPHORA RUBENS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   <U+FB01>ne deep red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Stiff; rigid; though       memhranaceous.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.   Flat, leafy, narrow wedge-shaped; forked or simple; ob
                                                                                                                                 scurely midribbed   at base; throwing out secondary shoots of the
                                                                                                                                 same formation from the upper surface; this second set throwing out
                                                                                                                                    a  third in the same way; and so on. The surfaces obstinately              crumpled;
                                                                                                                                     often covered with parasites.   Tufted.
                                                                                                                          Jleu-‘s'urz'mcnt.        From l to      8 inches   long.
                                                                                                                          F7‘uci1'<U+FB01>'cal‘[mz. Of two kinds.     1. A mass of spores in minute, roundish,
                                                                                                                                     wrinkled capsules; scattered on the surface. 2. Tetmspores in warts,
                                                                                                                                     formed at the base of small, leafy, scattered frondlets.
                                                                                                                          Ilabimi.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                        Our rocky shores generally;  but preferring the warmer stations.
                                                                                                                                     Under shelter of rocks near low-water mark.   Frequent.
                                                                                                                                          Very handsome when not infested by Melobesias and Zooyhytes;          but always
                                                                                                                                        a rather   unmanageable    plant to lay out, and never adhering   to paper.
                                                                                                                                Fig.         206.     PHYLLOPHORA MEMBRANIFOLIA.
                                                                                                                           Colour.        Purple, or purplish-red; fading to green and yellow.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Stems gristly; frondlets membranaceous, but rigidly so; especially
                                                                                                                                     when old.
                                                                                                                           Cha,racter
                                                                                                                                           of Frond.Cylindrical, irregularly divided stems, bearing irregular
                                                                                                                                     branches, all of which expand into <U+FB02>at, fan-like, or wedge-shaped
                                                                                                                                     frondlets, more or less divided and forked. Margins sometimes smooth;
                                                                                                                                     sometimes jagged with tiny lea<U+FB02>ets; especially above. Tufted.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           Measurement.             From   3 to   l2   inches long.
                                                                                                                           Fructz<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds.     1. ‘A mass of spores  in egg-shaped capsules
                                                                                                                                   on short stalks, fringing the stems. 2. Tetraspores collected into large,
                                                                                                                                   dark, heart-shaped groups (sari), in the lower half of the frondlets.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.        Our rocky shores generally; but preferring the warmer                  stations.
                                                                                                                                        On rocks between tide-marks.   Frequent.

                                                                                                                                                                        PLATE    XLVI.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.   209.          DUMONTIA FILIFORMIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dull purple; fading to green and yellow.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Gelatinous;       mcmbranaceous;        tender;      very slippery to the touch.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.           A simple stem, <U+FB01>nely drawn out and tapering to each end
                                                                                                                                 (attenuated);        furnished with long, simple, alternate branches, attenuated
                                                                                                                                    in the same      manner.    Both stem and branches cylindrical and tubular;
                                                                                                                                    <U+FB01>lled with a watery jelly.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.          Stem       sometimes    from 8 to 18 inches long, with branches
                                                                                                                                    from      4 to 5.      In     other specimens the stem is very short (from 2
                                                                                                                                    to   3    inches); and        the branches from 10 to 14.     In others there
                                                                                                                                    is scarcely any stem at all.                In   others the whole plant is small and
                                                                                                                                    thead-like (<U+FB01>lanzentous).
                                                                                                                                           Of two kinds.    1. Roundish   masses of spores (fzwellw)
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Fructt<U+FB01>cati'on.
                                                                                                                                  immersed in the substance of the frond.   2. Totraspores imbedded
                                                                                                                                  beneath the same; scattered over the branches.   Visible like dark
                                                                                                                                    dots through.                        -
                                                                                                                          Ifabitn‘t.      Our coasts generally.              On rocks, &c. at half-tide      level.   Common.
                                                                                                                                          Fig. 210.              NEMALEON MULTIFIDUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dull purple,       or    purplish-brown.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Gelatinous;       solid;    very   elastic;   <U+FB01>rm.
                                                                                                                          Cha/ractcr    of Frond. Cylindrical, about the thickness of a cr0w’s quill;
                                                                                                                                     once or twice forked, distantly; or simple; or irregularly, slightly
                                                                                                                                    branched.  Axils rounded and clumsy.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.          From       3     to 6 inches long.

                                                                                                                                  to the <U+FB01>laments which form  the  outer layer of the frond. Visible
                                                                                                                                  like dark dots through.

                                                                                                                                     near low-water         mark in exposed situations.  Not unfreqnent.

                                                                                                                                                                   PLATE      XLVII.

                                                                                                                                 <U+FB01>rst -quite simple; afterwards apt to be torn and divided; probably

                                                                                                                                       Fig.     215.       KALLYMENIA RENIFORMIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A <U+FB01>ne:    deep crimson.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Fleshy-membranaceous.    Soft and thickish when fresh; becoming
                                                                                                                                    thinner in drying.      Stems gristly.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond.   Roundish or kidney-shaped (broader than long) expan
                                                                                                                                    sions,  suddenly spreading from a very short, cylindrical, simple, or
                                                                                                                                    branched stem.     Expansions very irregular in shape and size; either
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    quite simple  or bearing along their margin frondlots of a similar char
                                                                                                                                    acter, and often bigger than the original      one.  Margins smooth,
                                                                                                                                    except when torn; rarely waved.            Root   a disc.
                                                                                                                          lV[oa,surement.      From    1   to even 14 inches in diameter.
                                                                                                                          Fructificaiion.       Of two kinds.     1.   Round clusters of        spores half   immersed in,
                                                                                                                                    and scattered over the frond.         2.   Tctmspores very minute;           imbedded
                                                                                                                                    in the    same.    Fruiting in winter.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.     The warmer stations on our coasts. Isle of Wight; Scilly Isles;
                                                                                                                                    &c.   The Orkney Islands (probably owing to Gulf-stream in<U+FB02>uence).
                                                                                                                                    Kilkee. In deep shady pools at extreme low-water mark.   Rare.
                                                                                                                                         The small form (K. mica-oplzylla    of Agardh),   exactly corresponding to the
                                                                                                                                      <U+FB01>gure in English botany, is frequently cast ashore in winter-time, in Niton
                                                                                                                                      Bay, Isle of Wight.     In this variety, the sturdy little stems generally give
                                                                                                                                      out several fronds; and the spore-groups are very large in proportion      to the
                                                                                                                                      size of the plant.  Two small lobes in the u per part of the present <U+FB01>gure
                                                                                                                                      represent this.  The larger sort needs more Gull)!‘-stream warmth than the Isle
                                                                                                                                      of Wight can boast of. Specimens from Kilkce would make a dozen of the
                                                                                                                                      Niton winter variety.                         .

                                                                                                                                                                             PLATE         XLVIII.
                                                                                                                                               Fig.       216.        HALYMENIA LIGULATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.         In      the   three   chief       varieties,    as     follows;      dicbotoma,   a. clear     pinky red;
                                                                                                                                     ramentacea, paler;          Iatifblia, dark red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.           Membranaceous          and gelatinous.             Ramentacea,        very thin.     .
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond. So variable that the varieties are classed into three sorts, as
                                                                                                                                     follows:—1. Dichotoma; compressed, narrow; often, though irregularly forked;
                                                                                                                                     the divisions of nearly equal width; tapering to both extremities.   2. Ramentacea;
                                                                                                                                     compressed   or nearly cylindrical;  full of gelantine; divided  into  three or four
                                                                                                                                     principal portions (lobes); tapering to both ends. 3. Laiijblia; <U+FB02>at; wedge
                                                                                                                                     shaped; either         simple      or forked;        or cleft into <U+FB01>nger-like          portions    (lobes).   All
                                                                                                                                     three sorts have their             margins          more     or    less   fringed   with frondlets;      latijblia
                                                                                                                                     least.       Root    a disc.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.             Dichotoma        from     6 to 8 inches  long; ramentacea from 12 to 14 long
                                                                                                                                     and from           § to an inch         in width; latifolia from 12 to 20 inches long, and
                                                                                                                                     from        2 to 4 wide     in the widest           part.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.            Only one kind known.                  Minute        masses      of spores, immersed        in, and
                                                                                                                                     scattered profusely            about the surface, as              if it   had been dusted with grains           of
                                                                                                                                     Cayenne        pepper.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.       Southern        shores of England.               On rocks near low-water             mark.       Rare.
                                                                                                                                        Variable as this plant is in growth, its “pinky colour, peculiarly soft substance,
                                                                                                                                      between gelantinous and membranaccous, and the innumerable dots of f'ructi<U+FB01>
                                                                                                                                      cation, are found in every specimen and sufficiently mark the species."     Hmvar.
                                                                                                                                               Fig.       217.        NEMALEON PURPUREUM.
                                                                                                                           Colour.        A    <U+FB01>ne purple       red which       is given        out in fresh water.
                                                                                                                           Substance.            Tender   and gelatinous;          slippery       to the touch.
                                                                                                                           Character       of Frond.  Long, cylindrical stems and branches.     Stem as thick as a
                                                                                                                                     goose-quill;  properly tapering to both ends, but the tip sometimes broken, and
                                                                                                                                     throwing out several lesser shoots; set with long, wide-spread, wavy, worm-like
                                                                                                                                     branches.    Branches simple or furnished with a second set, of much reduced
                                                                                                                                     size; all tapering          when not broken.                A     few slender branchlets       scattered irreg
                                                                                                                                     ularly over stem and branches.                       Root     a disc.
                                                                                                                                                    From
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           Measurement.                     ~} a foot       to 2§ feet long.
                                                                                                                           Fructi<U+FB01>cation.           Only one kind known.    Roundish masses of spores sunk among the
                                                                                                                                     <U+FB01>laments        which form the outer layer of the frond.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.        South        of England and west of Ireland.                        In   sandy places among Zostra,
                                                                                                                                     near low-water          mark.  Rare.

                                                                                                                                                Fig.   218.        NACCARIA WIGGII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A    delicate, bright rose-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Tender    and     elatinous;   adhering    closely to paper.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.                    thread-shaped -(<U+FB01>l1f0rm); much branched.
                                                                                                                                                            Slender;
                                                                                                                                 Stem undivided      or  once forked;  set with very long, wavy, horizontally
                                                                                                                                    spread, alternate branches, all tapering to the end. These re-branched
                                                                                                                                    with a second, <U+FB01>ner set of similar character.    Both stem and branches
                                                                                                                                    clothed  with very short slender branchlets, tapering at both ends,
                                                                                                                                    which   spring all round the stem. Root a disc. Internal structure, a
                                                                                                                                    slender tube in the centre, surrounded by large cells; the whole en
                                                                                                                                    circled in cortical branchleteens immersed in gelatine.
                                                                                                                          Measurenwnt.          From   6    to 12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Frudtlfication.    Only one kind known.      Spores immersed in centre of the
                                                                                                                                    fringing branchlets, which are then swollen (see <U+FB01>gure of a magni<U+FB01>ed
                                                                                                                                                                  ~-
                                                                                                                                    bit).
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Yarmouth and the southern shores of England. South and west
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                 of Ireland. Isle of Man. VVest of Scotland. Thrown up from deep
                                                                                                                                water.    Very rare.
                                                                                                                                    Fig.      219.      GLOIOSIPHONIA                       CAPILLARIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.         Rose-red;   though     scarcely when <U+FB01>rst gathered.
                                                                                                                          Substame.          Exceedingly gelatinous;        loose and slippery-feeling.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. Long, cylindrical,    tubular stems, profusely branched;
                                                                                                                                 bushy; tufted; each forming a more or less lanceolate, general outline.
                                                                                                                                 Stems undivided, delicately tapering to both ends; set with opposite,
                                                                                                                                    often quadrzfarious (springing from fo1u' points of the stem) branches;
                                                                                                                                    which are bushily rebranched with repeatedly divided branchlets.
                                                                                                                                    Branchlets very slender or thickened with fructi<U+FB01>cation; springing
                                                                                                                                    from all round         the stems.      Root   a disc;   throwing up several fronds.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.          From   3     to 12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.  Only one kind known.     Round masses                    of bright-red     s-p0'res
                                                                                                                                  immersed in the (then) swollen branchlets.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our shores generally. Filey, Largs, &c. In tide-pools, near low
                                                                                                                                    watcr mark.      Very rare generally.  Common in Jersey.
                                                                                                                                       Whimsical in its appearance and disappearance in different seasons, but there
                                                                                                                                     is -a large,
                                                                                                                                                                not very deep pool, on the lowermost ledges of Filey
                                                                                                                                                  transparent,
                                                                                                                                     Bridge, north,   vs ere it may generally be gathered by those who will wade m
                                                                                                                                     to reach it!

                                                                                                                                                                     PLATE      XLIX.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.   220.          DUDRESNAIA                    COCCINEA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Rosy-red; pinkish when young.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Very tender and gelatinous;               loose and slippery-feeling.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond.    Cylindrical stem and branches; rather distantly, and
                                                                                                                                     very irregularly divided (alternate, opposite, forked, or secund); each
                                                                                                                                     set  gradually <U+FB01>ner upwards.    Branchlets   much divided;    young
                                                                                                                                     specimens, when seen through a lens, looking as if beaded with rose
                                                                                                                                     coloured dots owing to the structure (densely-tufted, dichotomous
                                                                                                                                    <U+FB01>laments, whorling a colourless             aa:is.')
                                                                                                                          Measurement.         From 4 to         8 inches   long.
                                                                                                                          Ewcti<U+FB01>cation.       Of two kinds.     1. Dark red globules of spores attached to
                                                                                                                                    the <U+FB01>laments which form the outer layer of the frond.     2. Tetraspores
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    in transparent cells similarly placed. Very rare.
                                                                                                                          Ilubitat.        Southern     shores     of England and Ireland.              On rocks     near low
                                                                                                                                    water mark; or from deep             water. Very rare.                           ‘
                                                                                                                                      Fig.     221.        DUDRESNAIA                       DIVARIOATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Pale red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Gelatinous;     very soft;      elastic.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. A cylindrical, thread-like (filanwntuus), much-branched
                                                                                                                                 stem; undivided; set with long opposite or alternate, horizontally
                                                                                                                                 spread branches.  Branches three or four times re-branched;    all the
                                                                                                                                    branches      alternate;       horizontally        spread.        Branchlets   numerous;
                                                                                                                                    horizontal;       obtuse.
                                                                                                                          Measurezrwnt.        From      3 to 6 inches      long.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Frzwtz<U+FB01>cation.       Only one kind known.
                                                                                                                                                                  Globules of spores                         attached    to the
                                                                                                                                 <U+FB01>laments which form the outer layer of the frond.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         The warmer stations on our coasts.                    On   stones and the smaller
                                                                                                                                    algae near low-water    mark; and deeper.                 Very‘ rare.
                                                                                                                                                                Now Helminthora     divaricata.
                                                                                                                                23

                                                                                                                                                      Fig.         222.         PTILOTA SERICEA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Usually      a    dull, brownish-red;              sometimes      brighter.      Brown when old.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Very soft and limp; sometimes dense and almost spongy.
                                                                                                                          Character          of Frond.           Extremely          narrow;      sometimes        thread-like  (<U+FB01>lamentous),  but
                                                                                                                                    compressed;            excessively branched             in s formal manner.            Main stems irregularly
                                                                                                                                    divided; rough below with minute branchlet stumps.                                      Branches      re-branched;
                                                                                                                                    with short, curved, exactly opposite, horizontally-spread                               branchlets.        These re
                                                                                                                                    branchleted           once or      twice        in    the    same way.         Stem    and    branches      opaque.
                                                                                                                                    Ultimate branchleteens jointed.                                          of   a magni<U+FB01>ed               ‘
                                                                                                                                                                                            (See <U+FB01>gure                            bit.)
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>leasurement.              From    2 to     6 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.             Of    two     kinds.      1.    Clustered     globules       of spores, surrounded        with six
                                                                                                                                    or       eight    minute         slender        branchletcens          (ramellz),     which    fold    over      them
                                                                                                                                    (involueratezt);          stalked;      formed         at the end of the branchlets.              2. Globules       of
                                                                                                                                    tetraspores           formed     in the tips of the            same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     Our coasts generally. On perpendicular rocks between tide-marks.                                             Rarely
                                                                                                                                    on the stems of Fucus serratus. Common.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                       Now Ptilota               elegwns.   This is the only Ptilota found on the south coast of
                                                                                                                                     England.
                                                                                                                                                      Fig.        223.         PTILOTA PLUMOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A    <U+FB01>ne dark red; sometimes very clear and bright.
                                                                                                                          Su-bstzmcc.         Rather rigid.
                                                                                                                          C/zaracter     of Frond.           Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous), but <U+FB01>at; excessively branched in a
                                                                                                                                    formal      manner.        Main stems irregularly divided; smooth; set with branches
                                                                                                                                    of irregular lengths.   Branches re-branched; secondary set (and sometimes the
                                                                                                                                    primary)    clothed throughout  with shortish, curved, wide-spread branchlets.
                                                                                                                                    These re-branchleted    once or twice in the same way.     Stem branches and
                                                                                                                                    branchlets        unjointed; opaque.
                                                                                                                          lfeaeurement.          From       3 to     141 inches          long.
                                                                                                                          Fructt<U+FB01>aation.             Of   two kinds.           1.    Clustered     globules       of spores, surrounded        with six
                                                                                                                                    or eight minute, slender branchleteens (ramelli), which fold over them; stalked;
                                                                                                                                    formed on the end of the then shortened branchlets.    2. Globules of tetraspores
                                                                                                                                    formed in the tips of the same.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Northern and western coasts of Great Britain and Ireland.                                           On the stems
                                                                                                                                 of Lam. digitata. Frequent.
                                                                                                                                       The <U+FB01>rst set of branchlets are often not re-branchleted quite close to their
                                                                                                                                     base, so that the bare spaces look like a narrow white line between them and
                                                                                                                                     the stem. This is not the case in P. eericea, so that it serves as a clue between
                                                                                                                                     the species.
