                                                                                                                                                                 PLATE L.
                                                                                                                                           Fig. 224.        PEYSSONELIA DUBYI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Brownish-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Membranaceous.
                                                                                                                          Charade’ Qf F"°"d-      A thin, incrusting expansion, at <U+FB01>rst simple and circular; after
                                                                                                                                  wards cut into divisions    (lobes);   attached to whatever it grows upon by
                                                                                                                                  the whole of its under surface, which throws out woolly rootlets.         Upper
                                                                                                                                  surface marked by rings of lines (concentric
                                                                                                                                                                                  zones).
                                                                                                                          Jlcasurement.    From 1 to 2 inches across.
                                                                                                                          Fructification.   Only one kind known.       Tctracpores hidden among radiating threads
                                                                                                                                  in wart-like prominences.                               "
                                                                                                                          Habitat. North of Ireland and west of Scotland.           Probably in many places.    On
                                                                                                                                  old shells, stones, &c., on scallop-banks- in from ten to <U+FB01>fteen feet water.
                                                                                                                                                                               -
                                                                                                                                  Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.   225.      GIGARTINA ACICULARIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A dull purple-red; darker when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Gristly.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Cylindrical; wiry; irregularly branched; tufted; of much the
                                                                                                                                 same thickness throughout, all but the tips, which are remarkably pointed.
                                                                                                                                 Stems curved or wavy; simple or forked.          Branches  curved and re-curved;
                                                                                                                                 wavy; wide-spreading in all directions; once or twice re-branched.        Branch
                                                                                                                                 lets short, distant;    either alternate,   opposite, or forked; oftenest cecund.
                                                                                                                                 Root <U+FB01>brous.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 2 to 4 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind observed. Clusters of sporcs in globose capsules;
                                                                                                                                 sessile on the branchlets;    o<U+FB02>zen several together.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South coast of England.           Jersey.   Belfast.   On rocks near low-water
                                                                                                                                 mark.     Rare.
                                                                                                                                       For other Gignrtinas refer back to Plate   XLIV.   Fig. 201; Plate   XLIII.   Fig.
                                                                                                                                     197; and Plate XLII. Fig. 194.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.   226.      GINANNIA FURCELLATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Sometimes a pale pinky, sometimes a dull red, becoming deeper in drying.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Membranaccous;    <U+FB02>eshy; tender.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Cylindrical; the thickness of a goose-quill throughout; re
                                                                                                                                  peatedly and regularly forked (dichotomous) from a very short taper stem;
                                                                                                                                  forming a circle when spread.       Occasional specimens, midrihhed;    or some
                                                                                                                                  times constricted    here and there as if jointed.     Tips obtuse; broken ones
                                                                                                                                  sometimes throwing out fresh frondlets.      (See <U+FB01>gure.)  Root a disc.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Jleasuremcnt.    From 2 to 6 inches long.         Diameter of branches varying greatly
                                                                                                                                  up to half an inch.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind known.        Globular masses of spores, immersed in the
                                                                                                                                  frond.   Showing through, when held up to the light.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Eastern and southern shores of England. Ireland, all round; and very
                                                                                                                                  <U+FB01>ne; Scilly.    On rocks, &c. from low-water      mark to eight or ten fathoms’
                                                                                                                                  depth.   Rare.
                                                                                                                                                            Now Scinaia furcellata.
                                                                                                                                25                                        ‘I’             E

                                                                                                                                                   Fig.     227.        CRUORIA PELLITA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Blood-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Gelatinous;     leathery.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond. Skin-like; closely adhering; forming smooth glossy patches, at
                                                                                                                                     <U+FB01>rst circular, afterwards irregular in shape, on the surface of smooth rocks.
                                                                                                                                     Composed of minute, densely packed, upright, simple, or nearly simple jointed
                                                                                                                                     threads    (<U+FB01>laments).
                                                                                                                          Mcasurement.          Inde<U+FB01>nite, up to        2 inches     in diameter.
                                                                                                                          F   ructification.   Only one kind known.       Tetraspores, globular; divided                          crosswise
                                                                                                                                     (eruciate) in the middle of each <U+FB01>lament; immersed in an enlarged                           cell.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. On smooth, exposed rocks and stones at high-water mark. Jersey, Miss
                                                                                                                                 Turner. Near Gourock on the Clyde, Mr. Roger Hennedy. Very rare.
                                                                                                                                        Now Petrocelis           cruenta,   see   Appendix of New Species,              page     92    under
                                                                                                                                      Cruoria pellita.
                                                                                                                                  Fig.       228.         PHYLLOPHORA PALMETTOIDES.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Rosy-pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Membranaceous;         the stem elastic.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.   Flat; ribless; narrow-oblong or wedge-shaped; leafy; expanding
                                                                                                                                 from a cylindrical, simple or branched stem.    Leaves simple or once-forked;
                                                                                                                                 the <U+FB01>rst always wedge-shaped; bearing lea<U+FB02>ets from their surface or tips.
                                                                                                                          Jfeasurement.         From      % an   inch to 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fruotf<U+FB01>cation.       Only one kind observed.     Tetraqpores forming large oval groups
                                                                                                                                     (sori); lying across the frond near the tips; immersed in the substance.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      South      coast of England.         On rocks     near low-water        mark.    Rare.            -
                                                                                                                                                                      mm
                                                                                                                                                           For other Phyllophoras         see Plate   XLV.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.     229.         OROUANIA ATTENUATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Brownish or purplish-red,            fading   to a dusty     pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Gelatinous.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond.      Slender; thread-like   (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; much branched.
                                                                                                                                     Main     divisions  partly forked (dichotomous);     branches  alternate; more or
                                                                                                                                     less re-branched;     the joints clothed all round (whorled)      with very short,
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                     delicate, many-times-divided    branchleteens (ramelli).
                                                                                                                          lleasurement.         One or 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.        Only     one kind observed in England.      Large oval tetrasporee in
                                                                                                                                     transparent     cells; seated on the whorled branchlets,  either in pairs, or all
                                                                                                                                     round.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      South      coast of England.         Parasitical on smaller         algae.   Very rare.

                                                                                                                                                                   PLATE    LI.
                                                                                                                                 Fig. 230.          MICROCLADIA GLANDULOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A <U+FB01>ne rose-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Membranaceous,     though <U+FB01>rm.                                 -
                                                                                                                          Character of From]. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous),        though compressed;      of nearly the
                                                                                                                                   same   width throughout; tufted; much branched from the base, in an alter
                                                                                                                                   nate or irregularly forked manner; forming      a roundish outline.     Angles of
                                                                                                                                   branching   (axils) wide-spread; last branchlets short; tips either awl-shaped
                                                                                                                                   or split, in which case they resemble pincers.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.     One or 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.     Of two kinds. 1. Masses of spores in roundish capsules; surrounded
                                                                                                                                   by two or three short branchleteens (ramelli); sessile on the margin of the
                                                                                                                                   branches.   2. Tetraspores imbedded in the tips of the same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South and east coasts of England and Ireland. Hompton (N. of Hull).
                                                                                                                                 Bray.    Kingstown.     Scilly.
                                                                                                                                                                                                 I
                                                                                                                                                231.      CERAMIUM DECURRENS.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A dull purplish-pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of-1"rond.       Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>la/ments);   much branched.     ila F
                                                                                                                                   ments thicker than hog’s bristles below, gradually      <U+FB01>ner upwards; distinctly
                                                                                                                                   forked; naked, or furnished       with a few scattered branohlets;     the tips
                                                                                                                                   hooked inwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    Partially coloured; a narrow transparent space in the centre of each (see
                                                                                                                                   <U+FB01>gure), the coloured portion melting gradually into the white.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.     From 6 to 8 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.       Not observed.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.          On rocks and the smaller algae in tide-pools.
                                                                                                                                   Rare.
                                                                                                                                      Fig. 232.          CERAMIUM GRACILLIMUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A dark reddish-purple.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Very soft, tender, gelatinous.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.         Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); much branched.           Fila
                                                                                                                                   ments excessively slender, more so than a human hair; of nearly the same
                                                                                                                                   thickness    throughout; regularly forked,       or nearly   so; the    branches    set
                                                                                                                                   with minute many-times-divided           branchlets, spreading   fan-wise;   the tips
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                   slightly hooked.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Colourless. . Partition-lines (dissepiments), opaque, purple.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.      From 2 to 8 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind observed. Minute spores in large roundish capsules,
                                                                                                                                   sessile on the branchlets,     often two together.   With several slender branchlet
                                                                                                                                   eons, ray-like,   spreading below them; their tips forked.
                                                                                                                          Ilabilat.    South     of England and west of Ireland.         On   Corallina o<U+FB02>icinalis, &c.
                                                                                                                                   between tide-marks.       Not common.

                                                                                                                                         Fig.    233.      OERAMIUM STRICTUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Dark, livid purple, in deep water, paler and yellower in sunny situations.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Membranaceous,     but not very <U+FB01>rmly adhering to paper.
                                                                                                                          Characterof   F    rond.   Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); branched.        Filaments as
                                                                                                                                   <U+FB01>ne as human hair; of nearly the same thickness throughout; irregularly
                                                                                                                                  forked; distantly branched below; more frequently         and closely divided above;
                                                                                                                                   all the divisions upright and straight, with narrow sharp angles. The tips
                                                                                                                                   straight, or slightly hooked inwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Colourless.   Partition-lines (dissepiments), opaque, purple.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeaeurement.      From 2 to 4 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.       Of two kinds.     1. Minute spores in roundish  capsules, sessile near the
                                                                                                                                   tips of the branches;         surrounded    by several short slender branchleteens
                                                                                                                                   (ramelli) (involucrated).       2. Tetraspores  immersed   in the partition-lines of
                                                                                                                                   the joints.     Very prominent.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.     South coast of England.        South and west of Ireland.    On corallinee, &c.
                                                                                                                                   in tide-pools near low-water mark.         Not common.

                                                                                                                          Substance.      Rigid; rather harsh to the touch when fresh. Imperfectly adhering to
                                                                                                                                   paper.

                                                                                                                                                               PLATE      LII.
                                                                                                                                Fig.     236.      OERAMIUM DESLONGOHAMPSII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dark purple; almost blackish to the naked eye; on examination variegated
                                                                                                                                  with white.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Rigid (for so delicate a plant).
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Tufts of distinctly jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments). Filaments nearly
                                                                                                                                  as thick as hog’s bristles     below; becoming gradually <U+FB01>ner upwards;         much
                                                                                                                                  branched in an irregularly forked manner;        more or less furnished with very
                                                                                                                                  slender, simple or forked branchlets.     Tips <U+FB01>ne; straightish; spreading.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   In variegated bands. Colourless and transparent in the middle; purplish and
                                                                                                                                  opaque at and near the partition-lines (olissepiments).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 3 to 4: inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>catirm. Of two kinds, but only one clearly made out.          Tetraspores set round
                                                                                                                                  the joints; half-immersed;    very prominent.    The other, dark, irregular-shaped
                                                                                                                                  lumps like clusters of small capsules, sessile on the stems and branches.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.       On rocks, &c. between tide-marks.     Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.   237.     CERAMIUM DIAPHANUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Pinkish-red in general hue; but clearly variegated with white.
                                                                                                                                        Rather soft.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Tufts of distinctly jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments). Filaments the
                                                                                                                                  thickness of a hog’s bristle below, becoming gradually <U+FB01>ner upwards;       irregu
                                                                                                                                  larly branched; partly forked, partly alternate; re-branched in the same way,
                                                                                                                                  set at greater or less intervals throughout with short or long, more or less
                                                                                                                                  forked branchlets, much more slender than the branches from which they
                                                                                                                                  spring.   Tips hooked inwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   In vaziegated bands. Colourless and transparent in the middle, red, opaque,
                                                                                                                                  and swollen at, and near, the partition-lines (dissepiments), coloured bands wide
                                                                                                                                   thzoughout.
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurement.   From 2 to 6 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Of two kinds.       1. Minute spores    in roundish capsules, with one or
                                                                                                                                   two short branchleteens underneath; sessile in the last forkings, or on the tips
                                                                                                                                   of side branchlets.  2. Tetra.spores set round the joints.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     Our coasts generally.   On the smaller algae in tide-pools.   Common.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.   238.       CERAMIUM FLABELLIGERUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Dull purple    to the naked eye, on examination,    of different   shades.
                                                                                                                          Substance.  Rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) spreading fan~wise above.
                                                                                                                                  Filaments as thick as hog’s bristles; irregularly branched; partly forked;
                                                                                                                                  partly alternate; much re-branched above; set with forked branchlets.      Tips
                                                                                                                                  pointed; straight and spreading; or somewhat curved inwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    In variegated bands, but when young <U+FB01>lled with a purplish <U+FB02>uid which
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                  hinders their detection.   Afterwards colourless and transparent in the middle;
                                                                                                                                  purple and opaque near the partition-lines (dissepiments).   These armed on one
                                                                                                                                  side with a solitary, minute, coloured (when dry, white) thorn.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 2 to 3 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.    Of two kinds.     1. Minute spores in large irregular-shaped capsules,
                                                                                                                                  sessile on the branchlets, with two or three short branchleteens underneath.
                                                                                                                                  2. Tetraspores set round the joints.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.      On the smaller algae, &c. between tide-marks.

                                                                                                                                       Fig. 239.          CERAMIUM ECHIONOTUM.
                                                                                                                          Colo-ur.   Dark red or purple when young and fresh, variegated with white when old
                                                                                                                                  or dr .
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Itigid and harsh for so delicate a plant.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Dense tufts of distinctly jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments). Filaments
                                                                                                                                  slender, of nearly the same thickness     throughout; repeatedly and regularly
                                                                                                                                  forked, forming roundish outlines; frequently set with forked branchlets.      Tips
                                                                                                                                  more or less hooked in.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   In variegated bands. Colourless and transparent in the middle, reddish or
                                                                                                                                  purplish at, and near, the partition-lines (dzksepimenls).      These armed all
                                                                                                                                  round with a number of slender, hair-like bristles, sticking out in all directions.
                                                                                                                          Meamrement.       From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.     Of two kinds.    1. Minute spores in double capsules, sessile on the
                                                                                                                                  sides of the branchlets, surrounded by several curved branchleteens.     2. Tetra
                                                                                                                                  q>ores set round the joints.

                                                                                                                                                                       PLATE       LIII.
                                                                                                                                                Fig.    242.       CERAMIUM RUBRUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Sometimes clear red, sometimes darker; brownish-yellow   and white in decay;
                                                                                                                                 onexamination, of different shades.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Firm when fresh; soon turning <U+FB02>abby; giving out a pleasant smell.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>lanwnts).      Filaments sometimes
                                                                                                                                    coarse, sometimes slender; becoming <U+FB01>ner upwards from the base; much and
                                                                                                                                    irregularly branched in a partly forked, partly alternate manner; set throughout
                                                                                                                                    more or less with once-forked, or many-times-divided,     often secund branchlets.
                                                                                                                                    Tips hooked in.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    Coloured throughout red, but in different shades.   Darkest at, and near, the
                                                                                                                                    partition-lines (Jissepiments), which are always slightly contracted, and in
                                                                                                                                    drying often shrink considerably.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.        From    2 to   12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         Of
                                                                                                                                              two kinds.    1. Minute spores in globose capsules,               with two or
                                                                                                                                 three short, curved branchleteens underneath;     mostly borne                on     the   side
                                                                                                                                 branchlets.  2. Tetraspores set round the joints.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.             In    pools from high to low-water   mark, and beyond.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                 Very common.
                                                                                                                                                                    .~
                                                                                                                                        N0 description can include all the varieties of this most variable lant, but
                                                                                                                                     whether dark or pale, bright or dingy, it is coloured throughout, though in
                                                                                                                                     shades; and as there is but one other an-thorned British Ceramium (O. butry0
                                                                                                                                     ca7‘Tlltm) in which this is the case. the detection of delusive varieties is not so
                                                                                                                                     difficult as may be thought.      From C. botryocarpum it differs entirely in its
                                                                                                                                                                    -
                                                                                                                                     capsular fruit.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I
                                                                                                                                         Fig.    243.      CERAMIUM BOTRYOCARPUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   dull purplish-red,   fading   to green and yellow;   on examination,    of different
                                                                                                                                    shades.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments). Filaments crooked at the
                                                                                                                                 base; rather coarse; becoming gradually <U+FB01>ner upwards;    much and irregularly
                                                                                                                                 branched; in a sometimes forked, sometimes alternate manner; closely sot with
                                                                                                                                 numerous short, simple, or once or twice divided branchlets.   Tips straight.
                                                                                                                          Joints.      Coloured throughout dull purplish-red, but in different shades.                Darkest at,
                                                                                                                                    and near, the partition-lines (dissepiments), which are always                  slightly con
                                                                                                                                    tracted, and in drying shrink considerably.
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>lea-surement.         From   2 to 6 inches      long.
                                                                                                                                           Of two kinds, but only one thoroughly made out. Tetraspores set
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          .Fruct1:<U+FB01>cation.
                                                                                                                                  round the joints.    The other consists of minute dark fruit-warts heaped
                                                                                                                                  together in roundish clusters; sessile on the branchlets. Occasionally a true
                                                                                                                                  capsule, with two or three branchleteens underneath, has been met with.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our coasts generally.      On rocks, &c. between tide-marks.        Common.
                                                                                                                                           Besides the clumsy and unusual fruit, this plant is darker than C. rubrmn,
                                                                                                                                         and more purple.   Moreover, the tips of all the branchlets are straight, instead
                                                                                                                                         of hooked in.
                                                                                                                                    31

                                                                                                                                        Fig. 244.              GRIFFITHSIA EQUISETIFOLIA.
                                                                                                                              Colour.     Properly,       a.   deep or dark rose-red;               often brownish.
                                                                                                                          -   Substance.        Soft and spongy;               yet <U+FB01>rm.
                                                                                                                              Character       of         Thick cylindrical stems and branches; several times
                                                                                                                                                   Fromgl.
                                                                                                                                        re-branched       in
                                                                                                                                                           loose irregular manner; everywhere surrounded and.
                                                                                                                                                                a,
                                                                                                                                        densely clothed by rings (whorls) of tiny, incurved, many-times forked,
                                                                                                                                        jointed branchletcens (ramelli), set at very short, regular intervals.
                                                                                                                                        The     branchlcteens about             one-tenth      of an inch        long,    and overlapping
                                                                                                                                        each other.          Branches          and branchlets,        all   tapering      greatly to both
                                                                                                                                        ends.
                                                                                                                              llfcasurement.        From        3 to 8 inches          long.

                                                                                                                                                                             PLATE LV.
                                                                                                                                              Fig.   250.        GRIFFITHSIA BARBATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A beautiful, clear, rose-red; very soon given out in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft; gelatinous; tender; soon decomposing in the air, and after a few
                                                                                                                                  minutes’ immersion in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.        Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); forming a circle
                                                                                                                                  when spread out.       Filaments slender below; becoming still more so above;
                                                                                                                                  repeatedly forked; each joint slightly swollen upwards; the last few furnished
                                                                                                                                  with long, opposite, or surrounding (w/wrled) hair-like, jointed branchleteene,
                                                                                                                                  on which the tetraspores are borne.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 2 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Frueti<U+FB01>eation. Of two kinds.        1. Minute spores in globose, stalked capsules; enfolded
                                                                                                                                  by special, slender branchleteens (ramelli). 2. TBh:GsPO7‘8s, globose, borne on
                                                                                                                                  the hair-like, jointed branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. The coasts of the British Channel.         Jersey, &c. On the smaller algae in
                                                                                                                                  tide-pools.  Very rare.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.    251.        GRIFFITHSIA DEVONIENSIS.
                                                                                                                                     A beautiful, clear rose-red; very soon given out in fresh water.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft; gelatinous; tender; soon decomposing in the air, and after a few
                                                                                                                                  minutes’ immersion in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          C/zaracter of Fromt.      Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); forming a circle
                                                                                                                                  when spread out.      Filaments very slender throughout; repeatedly forked; the
                                                                                                                                  lower angles of branching      (axils) wide-spread; the upper narrow; the lower
                                                                                                                                  branches often throwing out root-like <U+FB01>bres which connect the <U+FB01>laments
                                                                                                                                  together below.    Partition-lines (dissepiments) contracted.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.     From 2 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fruati<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind observed.          Tetraspores  on the inner side of special
                                                                                                                                  branchleteens, which surround the partition-lines (dissepiments) of the joints;
                                                                                                                                   always below the last forkings.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South coasts of England. Muddy sea-shores in deep water.             Rare.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.   252.       GRIFFITHSIA CORALLINA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   beautiful,              which is very soon given out in fresh-water;
                                                                                                                                                          clear, rose-red;
                                                                                                                                   fading very quickly.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Soft; gelatinous; tender; soon decomposing in the air, and after a few
                                                                                                                                   minutes’ immersion in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Tufts of strongly marked, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); forming
                                                                                                                                   a circular outline when spread out.     Filaments more robust even than those
                                                                                                                                   of G. seeululj<U+FB02>ora;     repeatedly and nearly regularly forked;    the angles of
                                                                                                                                   branching (awils) wide-spread; divisions more distant below, very close above;
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                   each joint swollen upwards, pear-shaped;    contracted at the base.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.      From 2 to -1 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Frueti<U+FB01>cation. Of two kinds.         1. Minute spores in roundish   capsules, enfolded by
                                                                                                                                   special, slender branchleteens; sessile on the sides of the branches.   2. Tetra
                                                                                                                                   spores on -the inner side of special branchleteens surrounding the partition
                                                                                                                                   lines (dissepiments) of the joints.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.          On rocks near low-water mark; generally in deep
                                                                                                                                   pools.   Not uncommon.

                                                                                                                                         Fig.    253.      GRIFFITHSIA SETACEA.
                                                                                                                            Colour.    A bright transparent crimson; which is given out very soon in fresh water.
                                                                                                                            Substance.    Remarkably crisp and <U+FB01>rm when fresh; soon becoming <U+FB02>abby and soft
                                                                                                                                    on exposure.
                                                                                                                            Character of Frond.      Tufts of distinctly marked, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), forming
                                                                                                                                    a more or less rounded      outline.   Filaments as thick as hogs’ bristles; very
                                                                                                                                    straight; irregularly forked; angles of branching          narrow; lesser branches
                                                                                                                                    sometimes opposite; occasionally     throwing out below a few root-like <U+FB01>bres,
                                                                                                                                    which connect the <U+FB01>laments together.
                                                                                                                            Mcasurement.     From 3 to 6 inches long.
                                                                                                                            Fructt<U+FB01>cation. Of two kinds.       Minute spores in stalked, mostly double, capsules;
                                                                                                                                    surrounded    by enfolding branchleteens.   2. Tctraspores  crowded on the inner
                                                                                                                                    sides of special enfolding branchleteens.
                                                                                                                            Habitat. Our shores generally.       On rocks, &c. between tide-marks imder the shade
                                                                                                                                    of large algae.   Common.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.    254.       CALLITHAMNION PLUMULA.
                                                                                                                            Colour.    A beautiful rose-red.
                                                                                                                            Substance.     Delicately soft and tender.
                                                                                                                            Character of Frond.       Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) very much branched. Stems
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    undivided or somewhat forked; furnished with alternate or irregular slender
                                                                                                                                    branches; the upper ones longest and most divided; all the divisions and
                                                                                                                                    branches at one level (distichous);     every joint bearing a pair of short, hori
                                                                                                                                    zontal, or back-curved,     exactly opposite branchlets,  whose upper margin    is
                                                                                                                                    clothed with a second set; these sometimes with a third; all regularly set
                                                                                                                                    like the teeth of small combs (pectinated).
                                                                                                                            Joints. Visible throughout (when examined through the microscope).
                                                                                                                            Measurement.      From 2 to 5 inches long.
                                                                                                                            Fructi<U+FB01>cation.     Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in large, dark-red, double capsules;
                                                                                                                                    sessile on the main branches.        2. Minute, globose tetraspores borne on the
                                                                                                                                    tips of the then shortened branchleteens.
                                                                                                                            Habitat. Our coasts from Orkney to Devon, but in the warmer stations.             Dublin,
                                                                                                                                    &c.    On rocks, &c. near lo\v-water mark.      Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                    Fig.    255.     CALLITHAMNION CRUCIATUM.
                                                                                                                            Colour.     A brownish-red; soon fading to yellowish.
                                                                                                                            Substance.     Soft and <U+FB02>accid (limp).
                                                                                                                            Character of Frond.        Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); branched, but
                                                                                                                                     rather spazingly.   Stems irregularly divided into, or furnished with, a number
                                                                                                                                     of long, almost simple branches, which are sometimes rebranched.       Each joint
                                                                                                                                     throughout, clothed with one or sometimes two pairs of slender, upzight, some
                                                                                                                                     times simple, oftener re-branched, branchletecns.   These so crowded at the tips
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                     that they present a darkened appearance, like the eye in a peacock’s tail.
                                                                                                                            Joints. Visible throughout (under the microscope).
                                                                                                                            Jlleasurement.     From 1 to 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                            Fructzfwation.     Only one kind known.       Tetraspores, dark-red, sessile on the (then)
                                                                                                                                        shortened branchleteens.
                                                                                                                            Habitat. South of England and south and west of Ireland. On mud-covered rocks
                                                                                                                                     near low-water mark.    Rare.
