                                                                                                                                                                   PLATE     LVI.
                                                                                                                                    Fig.     256.      OALLITHAMNION BARBATUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A brownish or full red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Membranaceous,    and somewhat rigid.
                                                                                                                                         F
                                                                                                                          Character of rond.      Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); irregularly branched.
                                                                                                                                  Stems rising from creeping <U+FB01>bres bearing       opposite, or sometimes alternate,
                                                                                                                                  branches.   These long, and either simple or clothed for half their length (and
                                                                                                                                  irregularly here and there) with minute, opposite, spine-like branchleteens, which
                                                                                                                                  die down in winter.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Visible throughout‘; deeply coloured.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 1 to 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind known.        Narrow oval tetraspores, sessile on the lower
                                                                                                                                   most joints of the branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Ilfracombe, Penzance, and \Veym0uth.         On mud-covered rocks within tide
                                                                                                                                   marks.   Very rare.
                                                                                                                                      * “ When avamined under the microscope,” must always be understood in speak
                                                                                                                                    ing of these delicate plants.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.     257.       CALLITHAMNION BRODIZEI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A brownish red.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                                                                                     -
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft generally; stem elastic.
                                                                                                                          Character    of Frond. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; tufted or single; much
                                                                                                                                  branched.    Stems hogs’-bristly below, becoming <U+FB01>ner above; generally simple;
                                                                                                                                  furnished throughout with long, alternate, wide-spread branches, the lower
                                                                                                                                  most longest.    These bearing a secondary set, one to each joint, which spring
                                                                                                                                  in succession from each side of the stem (quadrifariously) ; the lowermost always
                                                                                                                                  longest; so that each branch has a spear-shaped outline.       Secondary branches
                                                                                                                                  once or twice re-branched in the same way.         Last branchlets somewhat back
                                                                                                                                  curved; bearing towards their tips a few secund branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Joints.- Obscure in the stems, which are somewhat opaque and veiny; visible in the
                                                                                                                                  branches and branchlets.                               .
                                                                                                                          lleasurement.     From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.     Of two kinds.      1.  Minute spores in large, roundish, solitary, or
                                                                                                                                   double capsules; sessile on the branchlets.    2. Globose  tetraspores, sessile on
                                                                                                                                   the branchleteens.        ‘
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.       On algae near low-water mark.   Rare.
                                                                                                                                Fig.       258.       OALLITHAMNION BRAOHIATUM.

                                                                                                                                    nished with short, alternate tufts of branchlets.       Branchlets upright, swi-
                                                                                                                                    shaped; not tapering to the base, but gradually upwards to a <U+FB01>ne point.

                                                                                                                                     Fig.        259.           CALLITHAMNION TETRIOUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A
                                                                                                                                       dull purplish-red or brown.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Rigid and harsh, but very fragile when once dried.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Thread-shaped   (jiliform); jointed; tufted or single; much
                                                                                                                                 branched.     Stems short and shaggy; dividing ‘into several principal branches.

                                                                                                                                 straight,   rigid, hair-like branchlets;    some simple;   some clothed with short,

                                                                                                                          Joints.     Obscure  in the stems; visible in all the branches.
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurement.     From 2 to 8 inches long.

                                                                                                                                   pairs, sessile near the tips of the branchletcens.   2. Minute oval   tetraspores,
                                                                                                                                   sessile on little stalks which spring from the branchleteans.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South of England. South and west of Ireland. On perpendicular sides
                                                                                                                                   of rocks, between tide-marks.     Frequent.

                                                                                                                                    fresh     water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Very soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froud.    Tufts of slender-jointed   threads (<U+FB01>laments);   excessively and
                                                                                                                                 loosely branched;  often entangled.    Stems set throughout with long, wavy,

                                                                                                                                 branchleteens.

                                                                                                                                    veins.

                                                                                                                                Fig.         261.         OALLITHAMNION TRIPINNATUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A     <U+FB01>ne crimson.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Soft and delicate; closely adhering to paper.

                                                                                                                                 whole plant at one level.     Stems furnished throughout with irregularly alter
                                                                                                                                 nate branches.    Branches set throughout with regularly alternate branchlets,
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                 beautifully  plumed like feathers.   Upper branchletocns, longish; lower, short,
                                                                                                                                 or altogether wanting; one, however, always rising at the base of each branchlet.

                                                                                                                                     guishes this plant from 0'. Bozreri, which it otherwise much resembles.

                                                                                                                                                                         PLATE      LVII.
                                                                                                                                       lb
                                                                                                                                    F'<>'.    262.        OALLITHAMNION ARBUSCULA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dark clarety-red,     or brown.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Stems gristly;     branchlets   very soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; single or tufted; excessively
                                                                                                                                 branched; bushy.     Stem thick at base; often shaggy with <U+FB01>bres; bare at <U+FB01>rst;
                                                                                                                                 then set with irregular, alternate branches. Branches twice or thrice re-branched
                                                                                                                                 with shorter ones, which spring from all sides of the stem (quadrz<U+FB01>zrious);
                                                                                                                                 and are all densely clothed        with minute,    overlapping  branchlets,   also
                                                                                                                                 guadrzfarious.    Branchlets   plumed with pointed, spreading or back-curved,
                                                                                                                                 simple or forked branchletcens, springing from each joint.
                                                                                                                          Jotnts.     Only visible in the branchlets          and branchletcene.
                                                                                                                          Ilfeasurement.        From    3 to   8 inches    long.
                                                                                                                          Fructg<U+FB01>cafion.   Of two kinds.    1. Minute spores in large roundish capsules;     sessile,
                                                                                                                                  two or three together on the branchlets.   2. Globose tetraspores, sessile on the
                                                                                                                                  inner side of the last branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      \Vestern shores of Scotland and Ireland, abundant.                  East coast of Scotland,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    rare.   Filey, plentiful on the north side of the bridge.                On rocks     and mussel
                                                                                                                                    shells, &c., from half-tide level to low-water mark.
                                                                                                                                                    Not found on the       same    stations   as   O. spongiosum.
                                                                                                                                    Fig.       263.       CALLITHAMNION FLOCCOSUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A bright     purplish-lake.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Very soft and <U+FB02>abby.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Dense tufts of hair-like, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) much
                                                                                                                                 branched at intervals.   Stems very slender;    irregularly divided into several
                                                                                                                                 principal branches, which are again once or twice forked Qdichotomous).
                                                                                                                                 Branches naked, or furnished    at rather remote intervals .with short, many
                                                                                                                                 times-divided  (almost tufted), alternate, lesser branches.   Every joint of the
                                                                                                                                  whole plant bearing a pair of exactly opposite, very short, very slender,
                                                                                                                                  pointed branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Joints.        Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Meamrement.            From    1   to 5 inches long.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.  Only one kind observed.                  Oval tetraspores borne on the branchleteene
                                                                                                                                 near their base.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         North of Scotland           (Orkney, Aberdeen,                 On rocks near low-water
                                                                                                                                                                   -
                                                                                                                                     mark.     Very rare.
                                                                                                                                         The fringing branchlcteens of this plant form so distinct                  a character   that it
                                                                                                                                      is impossible to mistake it for any other species.

                                                                                                                                Fig.          264.        OALLITHAMNION TETRAGONUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A      full or brownish-red, becoming darker in drying; but occasionally,                               when
                                                                                                                                    young,       brighter; turning orange in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Rigid;    elastic.
                                                                                                                          Clmraoter of Frond.     Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; single or tufted; much
                                                                                                                                 branched; thicker than hogs’ bristles below; becoming <U+FB01>ner upwards.          Set
                                                                                                                                 with branches which spring in succession from all sides of the stem
                                                                                                                                  (quadrtfarious); the lowermost longest; several times re-branched in a similar
                                                                                                                                 manner; the last set but one densely clothed with short, alternate, wide-spread
                                                                                                                                 tufts of branchleteens.     Branchleteens incurved; tapering at base; suddenly
                                                                                                                                 pointed at top; springing from all sides.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Obscure      in the stems.           Visible in all the branches.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          1
                                                                                                                          Measurement.           From 3 to 6 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation.      Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in large, oval, single or double
                                                                                                                                    capsules; borne on a (then) shortened branchleteen. 2. Tetra-spores excessively
                                                                                                                                    minute;   sessile near the tips of the same.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Our coasts generally.             On the larger      algze    near low-water       mark.      Common.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    Fig.       265.         CALLITHAMNION SPONGIOSUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A      dull reddish-brown;          quite   without gloss.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Soft and <U+FB02>abby;           holding water like          a sponge.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond.           Thread-like          jointed; single or tufted; much
                                                                                                                                                                                (<U+FB01>lamentous);
                                                                                                                                    branched.          Stems shrubby;      long; wavily curved; spreading in every
                                                                                                                                                                                branches
                                                                                                                                    direction; thickly clothed (especially upwards), with one or more secondary,
                                                                                                                                    similar sets.   These furnished   throughout with branchlets;    the branchlets
                                                                                                                                    crowded (especiallyupwards) with repeatedly forked (dichotomous) branchleteens,
                                                                                                                                    which, springing from all sides, give each division a rounded, bushy character.
                                                                                                                                    Angles of branching (axils) wide.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Obscure      iii   the    main      stems,    which     are    more    or    less   opaque     and       veiny.
                                                                                                                                    Visible in all the branches.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.         From     2    to   4   inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fruoti<U+FB01>oatfon.         Of two      kinds.     Minute spores in
                                                                                                                                                                           1.                               roundish      or    divided       (lobed)
                                                                                                                                  capsules;        sessile on the stems of the branchlets.                  2.   Tetraspores,    solitary; oval;
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    sessile    in the angles of branching              (aarils).
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally, in the warmer stations. Isle of Man. Scilly Isles.
                                                                                                                                 West of Ireland, &c. On perpendicular rocks near low-water mark; and on
                                                                                                                                 other algae. Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                                       Not found in the same stations                as   C. arbuscula.

                                                                                                                                                                        PLATE   LVIII.
                                                                                                                                   Fig.         266.
                                                                                                                                                            OALLITHAMNION                     TURNERI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A <U+FB01>ne rose-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft but <U+FB01>rm.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Dense round tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) rising from
                                                                                                                                  creeping <U+FB01>bres; branched.    Stems upright; simple or slightly branched; once
                                                                                                                                  or twice plumed like a feather (pinnate), with short opposite branchlets (see
                                                                                                                                  magni<U+FB01>ed    bit), very regularly arranged; the lowermost rather the longest,
                                                                                                                                  gradually diminishing upwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From an inch to 1§ long.
                                                                                                                          Fructifcation.     Of two kinds.  1. Minute spores in stalked, oval capsules, borne on
                                                                                                                                  the branchlets enfolded by branchleteens (involuerated). 2. Globose tetraspores,
                                                                                                                                  either stalked or sessile, clustered or solitary, on the inner sides of the
                                                                                                                                  branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.        Parasitic on several algae between tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                  Common.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.     267.         OALLITHAMNION                      PLUMA.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Crimson.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.        Dense, very short tufts of jointed   threads (<U+FB01>laments)  rising
                                                                                                                                  from creeping <U+FB01>bres; sparingly branched.       Stems upright; simple or slightly
                                                                                                                                  branched.     Branches naked below, the upper half plumed like a feather, with
                                                                                                                                  short or long, very upright, close-set branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.       One-quarter to § an inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Only one kind observed. Globose tetraspores,            stalked or sessile;
                                                                                                                                  clustered or solitary; often at the tips of the branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. The warm stations on our coasts.          Jersey.    Miltown Malbay.      Bantry
                                                                                                                                   Bay, &c.     Parasitic on other algae; generally on the stems of Laminaria
                                                                                                                                   digitata.   Rare.
                                                                                                                                       Fig.     268.        CALLITHAMNION HOOKERI.
                                                                                                                           Colour.   A brownish        or   rosy-red;    the two tints often found   on the same   specimen.
                                                                                                                           Substance.  Soft.
                                                                                                                           Character of Frond.        Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous);    jointed; single or tufted.   Stem as
                                                                                                                                  thick    as    a  hog’s bristle; closely furnished throughout with long, alternate,
                                                                                                                                     simple branches, which again bear a second or third set; sometimes springing
                                                                                                                                      from all sides of the stem; all set with very wide-spread branchlets, plumed
                                                                                                                                      like feathers; these re-branchleted with a second very short horizontal set.
                                                                                                                           Joints. Distinct only in the lesser branches and the branchlets.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           .ll[ea.vurement.     From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                           Fructi<U+FB01>cation.       Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in large oval capsules; sessile here
                                                                                                                                      and there on the branches.         2. Globose tetraspores; sessile along the inner
                                                                                                                                      sides of the branchlets near the base; either single or two or three together.
                                                                                                                            Habitat. Our coasts generally.           On rocks and algae between tide-marks.          Not
                                                                                                                                      uncommon.
                                                                                                                                         A rather woolly variety of this variable plant was once considered a separate
                                                                                                                                       species; C. lanosum.

                                                                                                                                Fig.        269.   OALLITHAMNION BYSSOIDEUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A beautiful rose-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Gelatinous;     exceedingly soft and delicate; rather glossy when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.         Dense tufts of excessively <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) very
                                                                                                                                   much branched.         Stems very slender, much divided from the base, either into
                                                                                                                                   several principal      branches, bearing a great number of lesser ones; or wholly
                                                                                                                                   composed of almost cobweb-like           branches, inextricably entangled together.
                                                                                                                                   Branches forming         a lanceolate outline;  clothed with long, slender alternate
                                                                                                                                   branchlets, plumed like a feather, with a second lesser set, and these with
                                                                                                                                   branchleteens;      all alternate.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Distinct throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.        From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructification.     Of two kinds. I. Minute spores in large oval, twice-or-thrice-divided
                                                                                                                                   capsules; near the ends of the branches.        2. Oval tetraspores; mostly solitary;
                                                                                                                                   sessile near the base of the branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. ‘Our coasts in several places.              Parasitic on other algae; on Codium
                                                                                                                                   tomentomm especially.         Near low-water mark.     Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                                   Like   C. roseum,   but much more cobwebby.
                                                                                                                              Fig. 270.            OALLITHAMNION POLYSPERMUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dull rose-red, or purplish.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frand.      Dense round tufts of slender, jointed threads ( <U+FB01>laments); loosely,
                                                                                                                                  very much branched.        Stems irregularly divided;     somewhat naked below;
                                                                                                                                  furnished with spreading branches above.       Branches several times divided; set
                                                                                                                                  with lesser branches; the larger ones bearing short, spine-like, alternate
                                                                                                                                  branchlets;    some   quite simple, others re-branchleted,     forming  feather-like
                                                                                                                                  plumes;     the plumes long and narrow;        the upper ones occasionally more
                                                                                                                                  compound than those below.       Branchlets   spreading, occasionally even turned
                                                                                                                                  back.                                     -
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 1 to 3 inches in diameter.
                                                                                                                          F ructi<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds.  1. Minute spores in large round   capsules; sessile on
                                                                                                                                 the branchlets.   2. Tetraspores set along the inner sides of the plumes of the
                                                                                                                                 branchlets;  very abundant.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.     On algae between tide-marks.   Common.
                                                                                                                              Fig.      271.       CALLITHAMNION FASOICULATUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A <U+FB01>ne purple-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.         Tufts of very slender, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) much and
                                                                                                                                   bushily branched.       Stems naked at the base, crowded above with long, wavy,
                                                                                                                                   very upright branches; their upper half closely plumed like a feather with
                                                                                                                                   branchlets.     Lowermost branchlets (or plumes) short and simple; upper, long
                                                                                                                                        spreading; re-branchleted once and again near the tips; producing    blunt
                                                                                                                                     andl
                                                                                                                                                                                                                a

                                                                                                                                   out ine.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Obscure in the nearly-opaque main stems. Visible in the branches. Partition
                                                                                                                                   lines (olissepiments)   contracted.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.      Two or3     inches long.

                                                                                                                                    of the branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     Yarmouth, Mr. Borrer.
                                                                                                                                                      Surely   only    a   “sport” of C. Borreri.

                                                                                                                                                                      PLATE   LIX.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.       272.          OALLITHAMNION BORRERI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   brilliant,or pale rose-red, in different specimens; giving out its
                                                                                                                                                          deep,
                                                                                                                                 colour in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Either rigid or very soft, in different specimens.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) very much branched. Stems
                                                                                                                                 nearly simple; bare below, or set with only short branches; above furnished with
                                                                                                                                 long, spreading, wavy ones; their upper half clothed with branchlets beautifully
                                                                                                                                 plumed like a feather, with straight, wide-spread, alternate branchleteens; the
                                                                                                                                 lowermost longest.    Branchleteens simple, or re-plumed near their tips: produ
                                                                                                                                 cing a round, blunted outline.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                                           From 1
                                                                                                                                                           inches long.
                                                                                                                                                        3
                                                                                                                          1l[easu-reme-nt.           to                     -                      -            -
                                                                                                                          Fructg<U+FB01>catzon.   Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in double capsules; sessile near the tips
                                                                                                                                  of the branchlets.    2. Globose tetraspores; sessile on the inner sides of the
                                                                                                                                     branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Our coasts generally. Douglas,    Hompton, South coast, &c.     On rocks near
                                                                                                                                    low-water mark.    Rather rare.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.    273.         OALLITHAMNION             AFFINE.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Pink or red.                         Substance.   Soft.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Character ofFrond.       Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; much branched; bushy; single
                                                                                                                                   or tufted.   Main stems furnished with very numerous, long, alternate branches,
                                                                                                                                  (which are re-branched.        Secondary branches long, alternately plumed like a
                                                                                                                                                                      ~,
                                                                                                                                   feather with branchlets. Branchlets (or plumes) once plumed with branchleteens,
                                                                                                                                   which are short and upright below; long and crowded upwards.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Obscure in the stems, which are opaque and veiny.           Visible in the branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.        Two or 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fracti<U+FB01>cation.      Of two kinds.    1. Minute spores in large, roundish capsules; generally
                                                                                                                                   two together.     Sessile on the stems of the branchlets.         2. Oval tetraspores;
                                                                                                                                   generally solitary; sessile on the lowermost cell of the branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Bute.        Once found by Dr. Greville.
                                                                                                                                Fig.          274.        OALLITHAMNION               GRACILLIMUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   When quite recent, a deep red; becoming rose-red in fresh water; giving out
                                                                                                                                 its colour if soaked too long.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Extremely soft and delicate.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Tufts of extremely <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments); profusely
                                                                                                                                 branched.    Stems dividing into numerous long, wavy, irregular main branches.
                                                                                                                                 Branches set throughout their whole length with a second similar set; these with
                                                                                                                                 compound branchlets; the upper ones beautifully plumed and re-plumed, with
                                                                                                                                 one, two, or even three sets of gradually diminishing branchleteens; the lower
                                                                                                                                 shorter, less regular, and less compound.   The whole branching at one level as
                                                                                                                                 if cut out (distichous). Outline of the principal branches broadly egg-shaped, of
                                                                                                                                 the upper branchlets long, narrow, lanceolate, pointed, strongly resembling
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    minute       fern-leaves.
                                                                                                                          Joints.  Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.    From 1 to 4 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in roundish double capsules; sessile on
                                                                                                                                 the principal branches.  2. Minute oval tetraspores on the tips of the (then)
                                                                                                                                    shortened        branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South and West of England. (Torquay, Milford Haven, Falmouth, Ply
                                                                                                                                 mouth.) On mud-covered perpendicular rocks and piers near low-water mark.
                                                                                                                                     Rare.

                                                                                                                               Fig. 275.              CALLITHAMNION THUYOIDEUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A    <U+FB01>ne rose-red.                      Substance. Soft and limp.
                                                                                                                          Character       of Frond.   Tufts (or single plants) of very <U+FB01>ve, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                    very much branched.     Stems exceedingly slender; nearly simple below, set above
                                                                                                                                    with alternate branches. These once or twice re-branched.    The lesser ones, and
                                                                                                                                    sometimes all, clothed with branchlets, which are beautifully    plumed and re
                                                                                                                                    plumed with one, two, or even three sets of gradually-diminishing branchleteens.
                                                                                                                                    The whole branching at one level, as if cut out. Outline of the plumed branches
                                                                                                                                    very narrow oblong.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.   One or 2 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.   Of two kinds.   1. Minute spores in largo oval caqisulas;   generally sessile
                                                                                                                                  on the sides (not at the tips) of the branchlets; very rare.       2. Globose tetra
                                                                                                                                  qzores borne on the tips of the (then) shortened branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts occasionally.      Yarmouth, Plymouth, &c.        On rocks near low
                                                                                                                                  water mark.    Rare.
                                                                                                                                Fig.         276.      OALLITHAMNION CORYMBOSUM.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A    pink or purplish-red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Exceedingly soft, limp, and gelatinous; having a <U+FB01>ne gloss when dried.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Thread-like   (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; excessively branched.     Stem
                                                                                                                                    hair-like below; cobweb-<U+FB01>ne above (occasionally much more robust); closely set
                                                                                                                                   with long, alternate branches. Branches partly divided in a forked manner;
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    partly alternate; re-branched in a similar way. The last series clothed with
                                                                                                                                    very compound, alternate branchlets.        Branchlets  zigzag; set at every joint
                                                                                                                                    with cobweb-<U+FB01>ne, repeatedly-forked branchleteons, of nearly uniform length;
                                                                                                                          ~         each tip, therefore, forming a roundish       outline, something like those of C.
                                                                                                                                    spongiosum; but not so bushy.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Visible thzoughout; even in the stems.
                                                                                                                          Zlleasurement.      From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          .Z'ructi/ication.    Of two kinds. 1. Minute spores in large, double capsules; sessile in
                                                                                                                                    the angles of branching      (axile). 2. Minute, round tetraspores,    a single one
                                                                                                                                    sessile on one side of the forked       branchleteem, immediately below the point
                                                                                                                                    where they fork.

                                                                                                                                    generally.    On rocks, algae, and Zostera marina near low-water mark.          Not
                                                                                                                                    Fig.     277.      CALLITHAMNION FLORIDULUM.
                                                                                                                           Colour.    A purplish-pink.                  Substance. Soft and almost spongy.
                                                                                                                           Character of 1'rond.     Dense tufts of <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads       (<U+FB01>laments), forming a
                                                                                                                                    roimdish cushion on the rocks.     Filaments equally slender throughout; once
                                                                                                                                    or twice forked; furnished with a few long, simple or forked, very upright
                                                                                                                                    branches; the upper ones sometimes clothed near the top with a few secu-ad
                                                                                                                                    or alternate, upright branchlets (the lowermost longest), on which the tetra
                                                                                                                                    spores are borne.
                                                                                                                           Joints. Visible throughout under the microscope, or even through a pocket lens,
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    having a peculiar shimmery appearance, from the silvery whiteness of the
                                                                                                                                    cell-membrane.

                                                                                                                           Habitat.     West of Ireland. Orkney.     Land’s End- Scilly.    Isle of Man. On sand

                                                                                                                                                                                  PLATE          LX.
                                                                                                                                          Fig.        278.             OALLITHAMNION ROTHII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Deep red or purple.
                                                                                                                          Substance.          Soft and velvety.
                                                                                                                          Character      of Frond. Dense tufts of very short, <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                     forming velvety patches on rocks.      Filaments very slender; of one thickness
                                                                                                                                     throughout,  slightly forked, irregularly branched.  Branches very upright, rod
                                                                                                                                     like; the upper ones sometimes set with a few sacund simple or branched
                                                                                                                                     branchlets, on some of which the tetraspores are borne.     Tips pointed.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Visible throughout.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.   From 1; to                1 inch        high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.           Only   one kind known.     Small round tetraspores,                       often   clustered
                                                                                                                                     together,      borne on the (then) shortened end branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.       Our coasts        generally.            Spreading        over the   surface   of rocks   at half-tide
                                                                                                                                     level.     Common.

                                                                                                                                    Fig.       282.        CALLITHAMNION VIRGATULUM.

                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.   Very minute tufts of <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments).      Fila

                                                                                                                                Fig.       283.           CALLITHAMNION PEDICELLATUM.
                                                                                                                           Colour.     A      <U+FB01>ne red;     easily given   out in fresh water.

                                                                                                                                                    thick as horse-hair,  loosely and irregularly divided. Branches

                                                                                                                                     furnished with short, alternate clusters of branchlets; sometimes one to each
                                                                                                                                     joint, almost; more or less forked and spreading; their tips very obtuse.

                                                                                                                           Iructi<U+FB01>cation.          Of two kinds.  1. Minute spores in large oval capsules, single or in

                                                                                                                                               sessile                2. Oval or pear-shaped, very dark tetraspores ’ or
                                                                                                                                     little colourless stalks rising from the angles of branching (awils).
                                                                                                                           Habitat.      Our shores          generally.    On   rocks   and   wood-work      near   low-water    mark.
                                                                                                                                      Frequent.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 -
                                                                                                                                                                   Now Corynospora podicellata.

                                                                                                                                                                        PLATE      LXI.
                                                                                                                                                    Fig.       284.      OODIUM BURSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Sti<U+FB01>y      and densely spongy.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    An irregularly round lump; composed of interwoven
                                                                                                                                 threads (<U+FB01>laments), densely matted together; hollow when old; several,
                                                                                                                                 of different ages and sizes, growing together in groups.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.          From      1    to 8 inches in diameter.
                                                                                                                          Fructification.    Little egg-shaped sacs (spomng-ia), containing a dark-green
                                                                                                                                    substance, which changes at maturity into seeds (zoospares; so called
                                                                                                                                   from having at one period a motion as if endowed with animal life);
                                                                                                                                    attached       to    the    outer   threads     (<U+FB01>laments)   of    which     the   frond is
                                                                                                                                    composed.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.        South       England.
                                                                                                                                                     coast      Jersey.
                                                                                                                                                               of         Cornwall.                            Torquay.    Not
                                                                                                                                    uncommon at Brighton. Very rare generally.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.        285.        CODIUM TOMENTOSUM.

                                                                                                                          Substance.         Soft; densely spongy.
                                                                                                                          Chara/3fer       of Froml.
