                                                                                                                                                               PLATE     LXVI.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.    306.      CLADOPHORA REPENS.
                                                                                                                           Colour.    Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Rigid; spongy.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Short,    dense, cushion-shaped, or globular tufts of jointed
                                                                                                                                   threads (<U+FB01>laments).     Filaments slender; closely matted together; rising from
                                                                                                                                   root-like <U+FB01>bres; slightly branched.      Branches simple or forked; upright or
                                                                                                                                   oddly bent; bare, or clothed with a few distant, secund branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Joints. From ten to twenty times their width; cylindrical throughout; i. 0. not
                                                                                                                                   swollen upwards like those of C. Brownii; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring     matter
                                                                                                                                   (endoclrrome).
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.     Tufts an inch or 2 in diameter.    Filaments scarcely Q an inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.      Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Jersey. Once picked up there after a gale.
                                                                                                                                          Fig.    307.      CLADOPHORA NUDA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dark green; or olive when dry.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Somewhat rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Loose tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), sparingly branched.
                                                                                                                                  Filaments slender;    very straight;   here and there forked         (dichotomous).
                                                                                                                                  Bzanches set with a few scattered, very upright, rod-like, close-lying branchlets;
                                                                                                                                  the angles of branching    (avils) being very narrow.      Uppermost branchlets
                                                                                                                                  often opposite and long, so that the tips of the branches appear three-forked
                                                                                                                                  (not expressed in the plate.)
                                                                                                                          Joints. Six or eight times longer than broad; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring matter
                                                                                                                                  (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.     Two or 3 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.    Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                 and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Portstewart. On basalt rocks in the sea. Unknown elsewhere, and only
                                                                                                                                  once seen there.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.    308.      CLADOPHORA LANOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Yellow-green; fading pale, and quite without gloss when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Soft; spongy.
                                                                                                                          Character ofFron1l.       Short, dense, globular tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                   sparingly branched, forming a circle when laid out.           Filaments hair-like;
                                                                                                                                   woolly; matted together; throwing out <U+FB01>bres from the lower joints. Branches
                                                                                                                                   straight, rod-like, alternate or rarely opposite; set with a few alternate or
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                   secund branchlets.    Angles of branching (axils) very narrow.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    The lower ones twice, the upper six times as long as broad; <U+FB01>lled with pale
                                                                                                                                   green colouring matter (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          llfcasurement.     An inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB02>cation.      Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally, but prefers the north.          Parasitic on various algae;
                                                                                                                                   often on Polyides rotundus; occasionally on rocks.       Common.
                                                                                                                                 57                                        *              I

                                                                                                                                        Fig.    309.     CLADOPHORA UNCIALIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Yellowish-green; but more grassy than the preceding, and not fading so
                                                                                                                                   pale when dry; the tips occasionally bright.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft and spongy.        -
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Short, dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), sparingly
                                                                                                                                   branched.    Filaments hair-like; woolly; wavy; the older ones inextricably
                                                                                                                                   matted together,    but in several thick subdivisions     throwing out <U+FB01>bres.
                                                                                                                                   Branches irregular; set with a few distant, eecund, long, spreading or incurved
                                                                                                                                   branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Jbints. From two to four times longer than broad; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring
                                                                                                                                   matter (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.     An inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our shores generally.       On rocks near low-water mark.     Common.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.   310.     CLADOPHORA AROTA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A brilliant, glossy, grass-green when young; olive and dull when old; at
                                                                                                                                    “a certain age” olive and dull below; glistening at the tips, which being in
                                                                                                                                    fact the youngest shoots of the plant, change last.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft, and retaining water at all times; coarse and very spongy when old.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Broad, star-like tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) rising from
                                                                                                                                   a wide disc of matted <U+FB01>bres.     Filaments as thick as horse-hair; spreading in
                                                                                                                                   a circle;  much branched.     When young, clothed with straight, crowded, very
                                                                                                                                   upright, alternate or opposite branches;        bearing  branchlets of the same
                                                                                                                                   character, but often secund branchlets.       When old, matted into rope-like
                                                                                                                                   bundles below, by root-like <U+FB01>bres from the joints; the upper branchlets only
                                                                                                                                   free.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Extremely variable in length; the lower, however, generally only once or
                                                                                                                                   twice as long as broad, the upper many times longer;            <U+FB01>lled with green
                                                                                                                                   colouring matter (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurement.     From 2 to 44 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Fructijfcation. As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.         On rocks from half-tide level to low-water mark.
                                                                                                                                   Common.
                                                                                                                                    Fig.   311.     OLADOPHORA GLAUCESCENS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A bright but scarcely grass-green; varying, however, in different specimens.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Soft and rather silky; having a speckled, shimmering look when dry, and
                                                                                                                                    seen through a pocket lens.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), excessively branched.
                                                                                                                                    Filaments very wavy; hair-like (but not so slender as those of C. r<;/racta),
                                                                                                                                    furnished with straight, erect, alternate branches, several times re-branched;
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    the lesser ones closely set with very upright, long, <U+FB01>nely drawn out, alternate
                                                                                                                                    or secund branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Joints. About three times as long as broad; nearly uniform throughout; <U+FB01>lled with
                                                                                                                                    green colouring matter (endochromc).
                                                                                                                          Jlfeasurement.      Two or 3 inches long, generally; but occasionally up to 6.
                                                                                                                          Fructtijication.    As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.        On rocks and stones between tide-marks.    Common.

                                                                                                                                                             PLATE     LXVII.
                                                                                                                                   Fig       312.   CLADOPHORA MAGDALENZE.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A dark, dingy green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Somewhat; rigid; not adhering to paper in drying.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.        Short, hair-like; jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) matted together;
                                                                                                                                   entangled among the bases of other algae.       Filaments bent, straggling, almost
                                                                                                                                   distorted,   irregularly forked;    with very wide angles of branching (axils).
                                                                                                                                   Branches     curved;   wide-spread;  set with a few forked  or secund branchlets,
                                                                                                                                   which are quite as thick as the stems whence they spring.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    Three or four times longer than broad; <U+FB01>lled with very dense, dark-green
                                                                                                                                   colouring matter (endochrome); the partition-lines (dissepiments) very narrow;
                                                                                                                                   not contracted.                                                                -
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.      One inch long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>calion.      Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Jersey. One specimen.
                                                                                                                                                         CLADOPHORA GATTYZE.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                        Fig.    313.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A dull, dirty olive-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Rather rigid; not adhering to paper.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Short jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) densely matted together in
                                                                                                                                   ropy tufts.    Filaments coarsely hair-like; irregularly branched;   somewhat
                                                                                                                                   forked; set with a few simple, wide-spread branchlets.   Angles of branching
                                                                                                                                   (azils) rounded.
                                                                                                                          Joints.    About once and a half as long as broad; very uniform throughout; <U+FB01>lled
                                                                                                                                   with dull green or olive colouring matter (endoc/aroma). Partition-lines (dis
                                                                                                                                   scpiments) very narrow; contracted.
                                                                                                                          Zlfeasurement.     One inch long.
                                                                                                                          1"ruct[<U+FB01>cation.    As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     Uncertain between Hastings and Filey. One specimen.
                                                                                                                                      Fig.   314.      CLADOPHORA FLAVESCENS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Pale yellow; glossy when dry.
                                                                                                                          Subslance.     Soft; silky; not adhering to paper.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Very slender jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) growing in long, en
                                                                                                                                   tangled tufts in pools and ditches, where it rises at last to the surface, forming
                                                                                                                                   a <U+FB02>oating <U+FB02>eece intermixed with large air-bubbles.    Filaments sparingly branched
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                   in a partly forked, partly alternate manner.        Branches long, upright, wide
                                                                                                                                   spread; set with scattered, alternate, or secund branchlets.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Eight or nine times longer than broad; <U+FB01>lled with light yellow colouring
                                                                                                                                   matter (c1ulochrome),nevcr very dense.   Partition-lines (dissephnents) contracted.
                                                                                                                          lfeasurement.      Inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                          ldructzl<U+FB01>cation.    As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. In pools and ditches of brackish or fresh water.          In a fountain-pond in the
                                                                                                                                   l\Iontpelicr Gardens, Harrowgatc. Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                 59

                                                                                                                                             Fig.     315.    CLADOPHORA FRAOTA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A dullish green; more or less light or dark.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Rigid; not adhering to paper.
                                                                                                                          C/za/racter of Frond.     Coarse jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) growing in long entangled
                                                                                                                                  tufts in pools and ditches, where it rises at last to the surface, forming a
                                                                                                                                  <U+FB02>oating <U+FB02>eece.     Filaments distantly branched; the lesser branches somewhat
                                                                                                                                  forked, and spreading with very wide angles of branching (aatils).       Branchlets
                                                                                                                                  few, alternate, or often secund.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Very irregular in length.        From three to six times as long as broad; different
                                                                                                                                  lengths intermixed;     <U+FB01>lled with dense, full-green colouring matter, which, under
                                                                                                                                  the microscope, is evidently formed into little grains (granules).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.       Inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                                              As before, except that here and there, when well developed, the
                                                                                                                                                               -~
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.
                                                                                                                                  zoospores   <U+FB01>ll the joints entirely, so that these become in fact a string of
                                                                                                                                  fruit-cells (sporangia).     This is usually observed about the middle of the
                                                                                                                                  frond.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. In pools and salt-water ditches as well as in inland lakes.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.      316.      RHIZOOLONIUM RIPARIUM.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Light, bright yellow-green     (sometimes darker); fading very dull in the
                                                                                                                                  herbarium.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft and delicately woolly; a peculiarity it retains in the herbarium.
                                                                                                                          C/zaracter of Frond.     Long, slender, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) lying <U+FB02>at on the sides
                                                                                                                                  of rocks, clothing them with a <U+FB01>ne close <U+FB02>eece.       Filaments entangled; here
                                                                                                                                  and there angularly bent, and sending out from the angles short, horizontal,
                                                                                                                                  thorn-like, jointed <U+FB01>bres, which rarely lengthen into true branchlets containing
                                                                                                                                  colouring matter (emlochrome).
                                                                                                                          Joints. From two to four times longer than broad.
                                                                                                                          Msasurement.      From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. As before, in the genus Cladophora.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts enerally.        (Filey).  On broad faces of sandy rocks near high
                                                                                                                                  water mark.     léot uncommon.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.     317.    OONFERVA ARENICOLA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Pale ycllow-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft; delicate.
                                                                                                                          Character ofFrond.         Extremely <U+FB01>ne, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) matted together;
                                                                                                                                  creeping; forming a thin <U+FB01>eecy web on the ground.      Filaments as slender as
                                                                                                                                  human hair throughout; crisped; wavy; unbranched.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Once and a half as long as broad, when old enough to be observed; <U+FB01>lled
                                                                                                                                  with green colouring matter (endochrome), which at last contracts into a dark
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                  mass in the centre, leaving the rest of the cell pellucid.   \zVhen young, the
                                                                                                                                  threads appear a uniform colour throughout, varied only by a few scattered
                                                                                                                                  dots.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.       Inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                          Fructz<U+FB01>cation.     As before, in the genus Cladqzhora.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. “On the sandy margins of pools in a salt-marsh periodically <U+FB02>ooded.” Rev.
                                                                                                                                    M.   J   . Berkeley.

                                                                                                                                                                 PLATE   LXVIII.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.    318.       RHIZOCLONIUM                OASPARYI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Light, bright yellow-green; fading very dull in the herbarium.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft and delicately woolly; a peculiarity it retains in the hcrbarium.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Long, very slender, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) lying <U+FB02>at on the
                                                                                                                                  sides of rocks, clothing them with a <U+FB01>ne close <U+FB02>eece.        Filaments entangled,
                                                                                                                                  curved, here and there angularly bent; and sending out from the angles short,
                                                                                                                                  horizontal, thorn-like, jointed, colourless <U+FB01>bres, which sometimes lengthen into
                                                                                                                                  true branchlets, containing colouring matter (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          Joints. From two to six times longer than broad.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      From 1 to 3 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Frueti<U+FB01>cation.     Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                  and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                           Habitat. Falmouth, and Penzance.
                                                                                                                                        It will be seen, by comparing the descriptions, that except in the greater
                                                                                                                                     slenderness of the threads, and occasionally greater length of the joints, there
                                                                                                                                     is no difference between this plant and R. riparium. And Dr. Harvey says
                                                                                                                                     that joints of different lengths are sometimes found even on the same threads.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                             F'<r.
                                                                                                                                               lb    319.      CONFERVA TORTUOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Pale, full, or dark green, in different specimens.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character    of Frond.      Slender, closely-interwoven,  jointed threads; (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                  forming a <U+FB01>eecy web upon rocks or algae. Filaments about the thickness of
                                                                                                                                  horse-hair; very much and sti<U+FB01>ly curled and twisted; unbranched.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Twice or thrice longer than broad; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring matter
                                                                                                                                 (endochrome).
                                                                                                                          Measurezrwzit. The <U+FB02>eecy web from an inch to several feet in diameter.
                                                                                                                          Fruot;'/icution.      As before in Rhizoclonium  (and Cladhophora).      See under Fig. 318.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.       Our shores generally.   On rocks and algae at half-tide level.  Very common.
                                                                                                                                              Fig.      320.     CONFERVA IMPLEXA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Bright green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft and delicate.
                                                                                                                          Oliaracter    of Frond. Very slender, densely-interwoven, jointed threads; forming a
                                                                                                                                  <U+FB02>eecy web upon rocks; or little tufts among the branches of other algae.  Fila

                                                                                                                                             Fig.     321.         OONFERVA ARENOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Pale green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Rigid and harsh for such very slender threads.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Very slender, interwoven jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), spreading
                                                                                                                                 in long, thin, <U+FB02>eecy webs, several of which lie, one on the top of another,
                                                                                                                                 like folds of gauze, and can be easily separated.  Filaments <U+FB01>ner than human
                                                                                                                                 hair, when young; when old, exceedingly rough, and apt to be swollen and
                                                                                                                                    lumpy (tubercular) here and there.

                                                                                                                                    matter (endochrome), which, when old, contracts into a variety of odd shapes.
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>leasurement.        The <U+FB02>eecy webs       a yard      or more in extent.         Filaments     5 or      6 inches

                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Coarse, loosely-interwoven,   jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) forming

                                                                                                                                    the   minute    grains      (granules)      which     compose    it   visible    under     a moderate

                                                                                                                                                 Fig.      323.        CONFERVA LINUM.

                                                                                                                                                                            PLATE          LXIX.
                                                                                                                                              Fig.        324.          CLADOPHORA ALBIDA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Pale, or sometimes bright light green; whitish, and generally                        without gloss,
                                                                                                                                    when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Soft, silky, and very spongy;                    retaining water and swelling     with it; soft
                                                                                                                                    to the touch when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond. Fine tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments) excessively branched.
                                                                                                                                    Filaments slenderer than human hair; crowded with long irregular branches,
                                                                                                                                    spreading       on sides, and several times re-branched;
                                                                                                                                                           all                                the upper branches
                                                                                                                                    straight; spreading;   often opposite. These set with straight, upright, short,
                                                                                                                                    opposite, or secund branchlets;  one issuing from each joint, and occasionally
                                                                                                                                                                            -
                                                                                                                                    bearing a second set.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Four     or    <U+FB01>ve     times      longer    than     broad;    <U+FB01>lled   with light   green   colouring
                                                                                                                                    matter     (enlloohrome).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.          From 2 to 6 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.      Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter                               in the
                                                                                                                                    joints, and in due time bursting through them.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          -
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      Southern shores of England and Ireland.  On rocks and algae                                between
                                                                                                                                    tide-marks, usually near low-water mark. Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                        This Cladophora approaches nearest to C. refracta. in appearance; but it is a
                                                                                                                                      much taller plant when well grown.      Moreover, it is distinctly spongy, which
                                                                                                                                      C. rvfracta is not; and it has a peculiarly soft woolly feeling when dry, which
                                                                                                                                      distinguishes it from all the genus but C. lanosa.
                                                                                                                                .            Fig.        325.         CLADOPHORA FALOATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        A   peculiarly      rich, glossy        green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.         Rigid; but          adhering   to paper in drying.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Froml. Dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), very much branched.
                                                                                                                                    Filaments thicker than huma-n hair; nearly uniform throughout; entangled at
                                                                                                                                    the base; irregularly divided;     much curved.     Branches zigzag;    curved and
                                                                                                                                    twisted all ways; repeatedly forked.       The last divisions crowded; three or
                                                                                                                                    four springing together from a stem.           These all strongly arched in one
                                                                                                                                    direction, like a set of curled feathers; their inner faces clothed with branchlets;
                                                                                                                                    some short and blunt; some longer and re-branchleted.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Joints.     Three or four times                longer     than    broad;   <U+FB01>lled   with dense green colouring
                                                                                                                                     matter (endochrome).
                                                                                                                           Measurevnent.         Three       or 4! inches long.
                                                                                                                           Fructi<U+FB01>cation.           As before.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.      Dingle Harbour, Kerry.                   Jersey.     On the bottoms      of clear rock-pools near
                                                                                                                                    low-water        mark.        Not    common.
                                                                                                                                    63

                                                                                                                                                     Fig.        326.a        CONFERVA ZEREA.
                                                                                                                               Colour.      A   beautiful    yellow-green;        fading   in the herbarium          to a dirty white.
                                                                                                                               Substance.   Harsh and brittle; but                unable    to support          itself when removed from the
                                                                                                                                      water.
                                                                                                                               Character    of Frond.        Long, upright, unbranched, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments),                      as    thick
                                                                                                                                         as hogs’    bristles;  growing in tufts from a disc-like root.
                                                                                                                               Joints.     About as long as broad, generally; occasionally longer; visible to the naked
                                                                                                                                         eye; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring matter (endochrome), which in drying runs
                                                                                                                                         close up to the partitions (dissepiments) leaving the middle empty.
                                                                                                                               Measurement.         From     J3 to    12 inches long.                                       -
                                                                                                                               Fructi<U+FB01>oation. As before in Cladopkora.

                                                                                                                                                                                      ‘
                                                                                                                                         quent.

                                                                                                                                            Fig.       326.b           OONFERVA ‘MELAGONIUM.

                                                                                                                               Substance.     Stiff; wiry; rigid.

                                                                                                                                                                 PLATE     LXX.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.      328.     CONFERVA                BANGIOIDES.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       Dark and very glossy green.
                                                                                                                          Substam‘/?.  Very gelatinous; soft; sticky.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Long, dense tufts of close-clinging, slender, wavy,
                                                                                                                                 jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), unbranched.  Filaments rather <U+FB01>ner than
                                                                                                                                    horse-hair.
                                                                                                                          Joints.     About twice as long as broad; at <U+FB01>rst quite <U+FB01>lled with light green
                                                                                                                                    colouring matter (endochrome), which afterwards contracts into a dark
                                                                                                                                    green spot in the centre.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.           From   3 to 6 inches   long.
                                                                                                                          Frzwhi<U+FB01>cation.  Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter                    in
                                                                                                                                 the joints, collected into a round central mass (spori<7ium), which                 in
                                                                                                                                 due time bursts out.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat. Breakwater,  Plymouth. Torquay.                 Port   Ballantoae,   N. Ireland.
                                                                                                                                  On rocks, &c. near low-water mark.
                                                                                                                                       Now Hormotrichum bzmgioides.    Like, but larger and longer than C. Youngana.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                     Easily known from most Confervae by its glossiness and soft gelatinous feel.
                                                                                                                                     From G. collabems by its quite different colour. For other Confervas see Plate
                                                                                                                                     LXXII. It should be observed that such Crmfervas (and I/-z/ngbyas) as have
                                                                                                                                     been removed to the genus Hormotrichum are remarkable for their soft, gelatinous
                                                                                                                                     substance, the shortness of their joints, and the contraction of their endochrome,
                                                                                                                                     at maturity, into a central spot.
                                                                                                                               Fig.       329.       ENTEROMORPHA                    INTESTINALIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A full    green; but apt to <U+FB01>ll with sand or dirt, and become dis
                                                                                                                                     coloured.     Fading to yellow and white.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Membranaceous;       thin.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. Cylindrical; tubular; unbranched; in<U+FB02>ated like a delicate
                                                                                                                                 green bag; widening upwards to a round broad end; tapering to a
                                                                                                                                 mere thread at the base; more or less wrinkled and curled throughout;
                                                                                                                                 several rising from a minute root; attached, therefore, at <U+FB01>rst, but
                                                                                                                                 afterwards <U+FB02>oating.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.  Often 2 feet or more long, but sometimes not more than an
                                                                                                                                inch.  Of every width between 116 of an inch and 3 inches.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.    Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in
                                                                                                                                  the cells of which the frond-membrane is composed; and in due time
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                                                              -
                                                                                                                                  bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.   In brackish ditches also; -and occasionally
                                                                                                                                 in inland waters. In a pond in the kitchen-garden at Bishopthorpe
                                                                                                                                 Palace, York. Very common.
                                                                                                                                          Narrow forms resemble E. compressa, but there is an unfailing rule for
                                                                                                                                       knowing them apart. E. compressa is                  somewhat branched, however
                                                                                                                                       little. E. intestinalis is always perfectly simp
                                                                                                                                                                                   alwayse.
                                                                                                                                    65                                          '             x

                                                                                                                                    Fig.     330.      ENTEROMORPHA                       OOMPRESSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A    pleasant, bright grass-green;           fading pale, yellow, and white.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Membranaceous;           thin.
                                                                                                                          Character       of Froud.   Cylindrical or somewhat compressed;       occasionally
                                                                                                                                    thread-like                 tubular; more or less branched.
                                                                                                                                                    (<U+FB01>lamentous);                                  Branches
                                                                                                                                    alternate; widening gradually upwards; blunt at the tips; tapering to
                                                                                                                                    a mere thread  at the base; sometimes simple, sometimes re-branched
                                                                                                                                    again and again.   Occasionally contracted at intervals as if tied in.
                                                                                                                                    Tips blunt throughout.
                                                                                                                          llleaeuremont.      From     } of an inch         to 12 inches long.     Of every width from
                                                                                                                                    a hairsbreadth     to    1}   of an inch.
                                                                                                                          Fructyication.       As in the preceding.                                    _
                                                                                                                          Habitat.      On every coast everywhere.      In brackish ditches also, and occa
                                                                                                                                    sionally in inland waters. In a large sheet—almost a. la.ke—in Clomber
                                                                                                                                    Park. Very common.
                                                                                                                                       Varying as this plant does in size. amount of branching, and bushiness. it
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                     may always be recognised among other Enteromorphas by the blunt tips and
                                                                                                                                     tapering bases of its branches.  In one curious variety the stems are one-sixth
                                                                                                                                     of an inch wide, fringed all over with hair-like branchlets.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.     331.         ENTEROMORPHA                     LINKIANA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A   very pale green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Mernbranaceous,          but <U+FB01>rm;     rigid when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.        Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); cylindrical; tubular; in<U+FB02>ated;
                                                                                                                                    rising with a main stem, set with branches on every side. Branches
                                                                                                                                    long, slender, between erect and spreading, tapering to the tips; re
                                                                                                                                    branched with a second similar set, only <U+FB01>ner; these with a. third,
                                                                                                                                    quite hair-like.   Tips pointed throughout.
                                                                                                                          lileasurement.      From     6    to 12 inches long.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Fructificat-ion.     As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.        Appin;    once found.
                                                                                                                                        The microscopic characters of this plant are very like those of E. clatlzrata,
                                                                                                                                     E.-erecta, and E. ramosa. The branches are-wider, however, than those of E.
                                                                                                                                     clathrata, and it has not the thorny branchlets of any of the three.
