                                                                                                                                                                        PLATE       LXXI.
                                                                                                                                        Fig.      332.          ENTEROMORPHA ERECTA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A   pleasant, light grass-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Membranaceous;              thin; soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous);     cylindrical; tubular; rising
                                                                                                                                 with a (generally) undivided main stem, closely set with opposite or
                                                                                                                                 alternate undivided branches; the lowermost longest;     all tapering at
                                                                                                                                 the tips.   Branches    clothed throughout with short, slender, almost
                                                                                                                                 hair-like, spreading branchlets, which give the plant a feathery ap
                                                                                                                                 pearance.    All the tips <U+FB01>nely pointed.
                                                                                                                          illeasurement.         From 4 to        8 inches       long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi/ication.    Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in
                                                                                                                                    the cells of which the frond-membrane    is composed; and in due
                                                                                                                                    time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.                    On rocks and in pools between tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                 Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                       The above description applies to the strictly characteristic specimens of the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                    species; so called          forms, that              is.E
                                                                                                                                                                                         .         ones abound, which
                                                                                                                                    are neither exactl tygicat
                                                                                                                                                           . erecta, nor    et    ttrata, ramu oea, or Linkuma, but
                                                                                                                                                                               Blultlintermediatza
                                                                                                                                                                                         c
                                                                                                                                    combinations froni them; and Dr. llarvey         of opinion that these four species
                                                                                                                                                                                            is
                                                                                                                                    are but one, under different circumstances of growth.       For the present, how
                                                                                                                                    ever, the variations take rank as typical characters;       and all that   collector
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      a
                                                                                                                                    can do,  isto place his intermediates in the set they come nearest to, on the
                                                                                                                                    whole.   He cannot go far-wrong so long as he keeps              with pointed tips
                                                                                                                                    clear of those with blunt ones. In the Nereis Borcali-     tho?mericana, E. erecta
                                                                                                                                    and E. ramuloaa are referred to E. clathrata.
                                                                                                                                Fig.        333.        ENTEROMORPHA                               CLATHRATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A   delicate grass-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Membranaceous;              thin; soft.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentozzs); cylindrical; tubular; bushy;
                                                                                                                                    rising with a (generally) undivided main stem, closely set with
                                                                                                                                    branches on every side; all tapering to the tips; occasionally inter
                                                                                                                                    woven and spreading in <U+FB02>eeces.   Branches several times re-branched;
                                                                                                                                    everywhere thickly clothed with short, hair-like,     wide-spread, or
                                                                                                                                    back-curved      branchlets.           All   the tips <U+FB01>nely pointed.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Ilfcasurenzent.        From     2   to 12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.         As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our           coasts       generally.     On     rocks       between tide-marks.    Not un
                                                                                                                                    CODJIIIOD.
                                                                                                                                       Distinguished from        E.   ramulosa by its greater slenderness,    soltness, and more
                                                                                                                                     profuse branching.

                                                                                                                                    Fig.       334.         ENTEROMORPHA                       RAMULOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A full       grass-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Membranaceous,  but harsh feeling; the thorn-like                           branchlets
                                                                                                                                    bristling when the plant is lifted from the water.
                                                                                                                          Cha,raster
                                                                                                                                         of Fro-nd. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous);   rather compressed than
                                                                                                                                    cylindrical; tubular; much branched, twisted and interwoven; when
                                                                                                                                    old, spreading in <U+FB02>eeces.  Main stems long, wavy; set with branches
                                                                                                                                    on every side; spreading     all ways; all tapering to the tips. Branches
                                                                                                                                    re-branched;    everywhere covered with very short, thorn-like, horizon
                                                                                                                                    tal branchlets.    All the tips <U+FB01>nely pointed.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurenwnt.           From     2   inches to a foot or two long.
                                                                                                                          Fructwcation.            As before.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.      Our       coasts       generally.   On   rocks   between       tide-marks.     Not   un
                                                                                                                                    common.
                                                                                                                                         Characteristic, really thorny specimens are very pretty, and easy to distin
                                                                                                                                      guish by their bristling -crispncss and full green hue. Dr. Harvey describes
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                      it as spreading widely in <U+FB02>ecey masses in its old age, and thus “forming a
                                                                                                                                      comfortable cover for a variety of small crnstacea and shell-<U+FB01>sh, who, no
                                                                                                                                      doubt, feel it quite their own."
                                                                                                                                    ‘Fig.          335.         ENTEROMORPHA HOPKIRKII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A   pleasant light green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Membranaceous;             thin; very soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. Long tufts of ultra-<U+FB01>ne-hair-like (byssoid I) cylindrical,
                                                                                                                                 tubular threads (<U+FB01>laments), excessively branched.     Main divisions
                                                                                                                                    long, wavy, tapering to the tips.  Branches upright; opposite or al
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   ’
                                                                                                                                    ternate; repeatcdly divided; springing from all sides; set profusely
                                                                                                                                    with minute cobwebby branchlets;                 all the tips <U+FB01>nely pointed.
                                                                                                                                                                                                    I
                                                                                                                          Zlleasurement.           From     6 to 12 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Idructzzfication.         As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.       Carrickfergus.             Goodington.                               in from four to
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                                                                    Torbay.    Dredged
                                                                                                                                    ten fathoms’ water.              Rare.
                                                                                                                                        As delicate as the most delicate of the Olado horas. Under the microscope,
                                                                                                                                      remarkable for the large size of cells of which the frond is composed; and
                                                                                                                                      that these are empty, all but a minute grain of bright green colouring matter
                                                                                                                                      (wndochrome)  in the middle. As the branchlets are termed of only one row of
                                                                                                                                      these cells, they appear to be jointed like those of a Uladophora.

                                                                                                                                                                       PLATE   LXXII.
                                                                                                                                                 Fig.     336.     CONFERVA SUTORIA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft.
                                                                                                                          Character   of Frond. Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); jointed; forming <U+FB02>oating and loosely
                                                                                                                                  entangled <U+FB02>eeces in ditches and pools.     Filaments almost the thickness of a
                                                                                                                                  hog’s bristle, equal throughout; very long, wavy, unbranched.
                                                                                                                          Joints.   Once and a half as long as broad; <U+FB01>lled with green colouring matter (endo
                                                                                                                                   chroma).
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.    Inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                          Fruct1_T<U+FB01>cation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the
                                                                                                                                 joints, and in due time bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Wisbeach, &c. In ditches and pools subject to the in<U+FB02>uence of the tides;
                                                                                                                                 sometimes found growing with C. Linum.
                                                                                                                                         Like   O.   Linum but a much slenderer plant, with longer proportioned             joints.
                                                                                                                                                Fig.    337.     OONFERVA YOUNGANA.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Grass-green; not glossy when dry; fading to a dull brownish orange in the
                                                                                                                                   herbal-ium.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft, but <U+FB01>rm.   Rather woolly to the touch when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Short (or sometimes long), dense tufts of jointed threads (<U+FB01>l
                                                                                                                                   aments), spreading   over the surface of rocks and wood-work.      Filaments as
                                                                                                                                   <U+FB01>ne as human hair; straight, or nearly so; clinging together; unbranched.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Very variable in length.      Generally once and a half as long as broad, but
                                                                                                                                   sometimes twice as long, and sometimes only half; at <U+FB01>rst, quite <U+FB01>lled with
                                                                                                                                   dense, bright green endochrome, which afterwards contracts into a dark spot
                                                                                                                                   in the centre.
                                                                                                                          llleaeu/rement.    One or 2 inches high.
                                                                                                                          Frueti/ication. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   collected into a round central    mass (sporidium), which in due time bursts
                                                                                                                                   out.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.    Our coasts generally.  Near Dunraven Castle.    Filey, &c. Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                                 N ow   Hormotrichum    Younganum.    See under      Figure    328.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.       338.     OCHLOOHZETE                      HYSTRIX.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Pale green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Harsh, for so in<U+FB01>nitesimally-sized a plant!
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     A minute hairy patch formed of jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments),
                                                                                                                                 radiating from a centre, and so forming a round dot.   The <U+FB01>laments some
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                   what branched,    and usually   sending           up   long,   stiff,   transparent,   unjointed
                                                                                                                                   bristles from almost every joint.
                                                                                                                          Jlfeaeurement.    A homueopathic globule!
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Unknown.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. In brackish water near the coast;                 and sometimes         in inland ditches, on
                                                                                                                                 stems of grasses, leaves of mosses, &c.             Very rare.                                  ,
                                                                                                                                           The plate is incorrect in representing     the bristles    as green,   they are;colour
                                                                                                                                         less and transparent.
                                                                                                                                    69

                                                                                                                                Fig.    339.     ENTEROMORPHA OORNUCOPIZE.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Dark green below; pale above.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Meinbranaceous;   thin.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Tubular, in<U+FB02>ated, bag-like, widening suddenly upwards from a
                                                                                                                                   thead-like   base; by degrees spreading at top like a funnel, and <U+FB01>nally torn
                                                                                                                                   and open.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.      About an inch high.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the cells
                                                                                                                                   of which the frond-membrane        is   composed, and in due time     bursting
                                                                                                                                   through them.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. On corallines in rocky pools left by the tide. Not “generally observed."
                                                                                                                                    So very like a dwarf variety of E. intestinalis. that Dr. Harvey hesitates
                                                                                                                                  about it. The species was constituted by a well-known algologist now dead,
                                                                                                                                  and for the present stands.
                                                                                                                                  Fig.    340.      ENTEROMORPHA                     PEROURSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Bright grass-green; fading when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Membranaceous;     soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Entangled tufts of very slender (almost hair-like) threads
                                                                                                                                              spreading widely on oozy shores.  Filaments nearly solid, but just
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:04 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                  (<U+FB01>laments)
                                                                                                                                  tubular, so as to keep up the character of an Enteromorpha; rather more
                                                                                                                                  twisted than in E. Ralféii; simple and unbranched, or bearing (rarely) a few
                                                                                                                                  short, slender, spine-like branchlets.
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>lcasurement.    Several inches long.     Two or more (but generally only two) cells
                                                                                                                                  forming its almost hairsbreadth width. The cells small (compared with those
                                                                                                                                  of E. Ra]/til); square; the colouring matter (endochrome) nearly <U+FB01>lling them,
                                                                                                                                  and being subdivided into four in<U+FB01>nitesimal  portions.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. On muddy sea shores above half-tide level.
                                                                                                                                            These last two <U+FB01>gures are misplaced    on the plate.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.    341.     ENTEROMORPHA                      RALFSII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Bright grass-green; fading when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Membranaceous;    soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frand.       Entangled tufts of very slender (almost hair-like) threads
                                                                                                                                   (<U+FB01>laments) spreading widely on oozy shores.     Filaments nearly solid, but just
                                                                                                                                   tubular; so as to keep up the character of an Entoromorpha; simple and un
                                                                                                                                   branched, or bearing a few short, slender, spine-like branchlets.
                                                                                                                          llfeasuremcnt.    Several inches long.     From 2 to 4: cells forming its almost hairs
                                                                                                                                   breadth width!     The cells large (compared to those of E. percursa); oblong,
                                                                                                                                   transparent;   each containing a. central grain of bright green colouring mat
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                 ter (e-ndochrome).
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>catim.    As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. On muddy sea-shores above half-tide level.       Mr. Ralfs.
                                                                                                                                     The characters which separate this plant from E. percursa are microscopic,
                                                                                                                                   in more senses than one, as a comparison of the descriptions will show. In
                                                                                                                                   E. Rulfsii the endochrome forms a minute dot in the centre of a transparent
                                                                                                                                   cell; in E. percurm it is a square mass, and nearly as large as the cell itself.
                                                                                                                                   Sec Figs. 340 and 341.
                                                                                                                                                                                                           70

                                                                                                                                                                 PLATE        LXXIII.
                                                                                                                                                 Fig.     342.      ULVA LATISSIMA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A full, bright green; darker from deep water;                 fading pale;   some
                                                                                                                                    times turning brown in drying.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Membranaceous;         but quite crisp when fresh.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond. A ribless expansion of very irregular shape; broad or
                                                                                                                                 oblong; simple or divided; wavy or <U+FB02>at; often plaited; one or more
                                                                                                                                 growing together from one base.                             -
                                                                                                                          illeasureznent.       From    6 inches    to   2   feet long;   from 3 to 12 inches wide.
                                                                                                                          Frzwti<U+FB01>cation.    Minute seeds (zoosporm) formed of the colouring matter in
                                                                                                                                  the cells of which the frond-membrane is composed; and in due time
                                                                                                                                  bursting through them.
                                                                                                                          Ilubitaf.     Our coasts        generally.     On rocks,    &c. between tide-marks.          Very
                                                                                                                                     common.
                                                                                                                                         Called “green laver,” in contradistinction        to the purple laver (Porphyra.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                      laciniata).   Some authors call this species Phycoseris latissima; thus separating
                                                                                                                                      it from the true Ul-vas, which have the frond-membrane composed of only one
                                                                                                                                      layer of little cells (cellules); whereas that of Ulva. latiss-ima is composed of two.
                                                                                                                                      Dr. Harvey, however, retains both under the genus Ulva, but points out the
                                                                                                                                      difference.   This is only to be ascertained by dissection and examination under
                                                                                                                                      a microscope;     but as a membrane with two cells is naturally thicker than
                                                                                                                                      those with but one, the <U+FB01>rmer texture forms a distinguishing mark between
                                                                                                                                      this plant and the following.
                                                                                                                                                   Fig.     343.         ULVA LACTUCA.
                                                                                                                           Colour.     A pleasant light green, fading to yellowish;              sometimes darker when
                                                                                                                                                 -
                                                                                                                                     young.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Delicately          membranaceous;           almost    transparent;     somewhat
                                                                                                                                 gelatinous; thin.
                                                                                                                           Character     of Fr0ud.   When young,                a puckered    in<U+FB02>ated bag; afterwards
                                                                                                                                     bursting, and opening out into             a <U+FB02>at, ribless, wavy or torn, more or
                                                                                                                                      less rounded expansion.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                           Jlleas-urmamt.
                                                                                                                                                 From   3 to 6 inches        long, and as much wide.
                                                                                                                           Fructi<U+FB01>cation.        As before.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.      Our coasts generally.           On rocks, &c. between tide-marks.          Not so
                                                                                                                                      common as U. latissima.
                                                                                                                                           This is a true Ulva, the frond-membrane        being composed of only one    layer
                                                                                                                                         of little cells (cellules).
                                                                                                                                    71

                                                                                                                                                       Fig.      344.       ULVA LINZA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A   <U+FB01>ne grass-green,         fading in the herbarium.
                                                                                                                          »S"ubsia,1u'e.     Membranaceous;          soft and thin.
                                                                                                                          Character        of Froml.         A   long,    narrow,      ribless,leaf-like expansion, with
                                                                                                                                    curled     and  wavy margins;           either     blunt or pointed at top, always
                                                                                                                                    tapering     to the base.
                                                                                                                          Mbmmrenwnt.           From     6 inches to 2 feet          long; from § inch to          2   inches wide.
                                                                                                                                                                                                   ‘
                                                                                                                          Fmwti<U+FB01>cation.         As before.
                                                                                                                          Ifabitat.        Our coasts generally.            On      rocks,   &c.       at   half-tide level.    Not
                                                                                                                                                         -
                                                                                                                                    uncommon.
                                                                                                                                        The structure of the Uhm. has another peculiarity.       It is formed of two
                                                                                                                                      membranes (each one cell thick) so closely laid together. that their existence as
                                                                                                                                      two can only be ascertained by microscopic investigation.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                            Fig.     345.        PORPHYRA LAOINIATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Dull purple when growing; occasionally greenish; becoming bright
                                                                                                                                    and very glossy when steeped in fresh water and afterwards laid out
                                                                                                                                    and dried.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Delicately   membranaceous;             sometimes extremely thin; sometimes
                                                                                                                                    thicker and <U+FB01>rmer.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     A <U+FB01>at, broad, ribless expansion; sometimes irregularly
                                                                                                                                 divided, or   torn; sometimes growing in an irregular circle from a
                                                                                                                                 central root.    One or more from one base.
                                                                                                                          Mcasvzrement.         From 4 to        8   inches or more across.
                                                                                                                          Fmcfi<U+FB01>cation.         Minute       seeds    (zoospores)    formed of the colouring matter in
                                                                                                                                    the cells (four together) of which                the frond-membrane is composed;
                                                                                                                                    and in due time dropping out.
                                                                                                                          Ilabitat.        Our coasts generally.          On rocks, &c. within the range of the tide.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    Common.
                                                                                                                                        This is the Iaver sold in jars in the shops, and is a great delicacy when
                                                                                                                                      stewed and eaten hot with lemon-juice.    But it should be served up like Hans
                                                                                                                                      Andersen's white snails, in a silver dish with a spirit-lamp underneath.     It is
                                                                                                                                      called sloko, or slokaun, in Scotland and Ireland, where it is often gathered for
                                                                                                                                      food under that or some other odd name. At Miltown Malbay and Kilkee, it
                                                                                                                                      is called “Z-ibberum."

                                                                                                                                                                       PLATE     LXXIV.
                                                                                                                                              Fig.       346.        PORPHYRA                 VULGARIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Bright   purple;    almost    rosy when dry;      very glossy.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Delicately membranaceous;          very   thin.
                                                                                                                          Character       of Frond.A <U+FB02>at, narrow,             ribless, leafy expansion, with a pointed end.
                                                                                                                                    Quite  simple; but the margins            becoming more or less strongly waved and
                                                                                                                                    plaited as the plant grows.
                                                                                                                          illeasurement.   From an inch to               I
                                                                                                                                                               or 2 feet long.                   Not   more than    3    inches wide,
                                                                                                                                   and young specimens mere threads.
                                                                                                                          Frucli/Zcation.   Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the cells
                                                                                                                                   of which the frond-membrane is composed (four in each cell); and in due time
                                                                                                                                   dropping out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.        Our coasts generally.         On rocks, doc. between tide-marks;         from high-water
                                                                                                                                    mark     downwards.
                                                                                                                                        It is almost “ past a peradventure " that this plant is but a different condition
                                                                                                                                     of the preceding one, Porphyra laciniata (see last Plate). The narrowest of the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                     specimens in Fig.346 are found in winter or early spring covering the rocks
                                                                                                                                     near high-water mark with their tiny. purplish-pink, satiny fronds.         Later in
                                                                                                                                     the season, the larger, frilled form abounds in the same locality, as also lower
                                                                                                                                     on the shore, where it may be found mixed with the broad divided fronds of
                                                                                                                                     P. laciniata. All are gathered indiscriminately for the table. P. vulgaris is
                                                                                                                                     rarely so dull coloured and greenish as P. laciniafa often is; but, on the other
                                                                                                                                     hand, P. laciniatn. is sometimes as bright as the other ever is. And intermediate
                                                                                                                                     instances both in form and colour are met with.       Dr. Harvey unites the species
                                                                                                                                     in his Nereis Boreali-Americana,    under the name laciniata.
                                                                                                                                         Fig.     347.       'BANGIA FUSOO-PURPUREA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Blackish-purple;      occasionally   greenish;    glossy.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Tenacious;      soft;   sticky.
                                                                                                                          Character     of Frond. Tufts of hair-like threads (<U+FB01>laments); forming a close-clinging,
                                                                                                                                    dark purple or greenish layer upon rocks.      Filaments straight or slightly
                                                                                                                                    curled; undivided; unbranched;   tubular; containing ro\vs of minute colour
                                                                                                                                    cells radiating from the centre.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.        Filaments, several inches long; their width variable; narrow ones
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                    containing only one colour-cell;   others from 2 up to 5; these forming (with
                                                                                                                                    the intervals) a tesselated line across (see Figure for magni<U+FB01>ed appearance of
                                                                                                                                    this strictly microscopic object.)
                                                                                                                          Fructl/ioation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colour-cells                     in the <U+FB01>laments
                                                                                                                                   (one to each cell); and in due time dropping out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our  coasts generally, and in          fresh-water rivers       and canals.     On rocks,
                                                                                                                                    wood,    &c. near high-water mark.            Not  uncommon.
                                                                                                                                    73                                                "‘               1

                                                                                                                                                   Fig.     348.            BANGIA OILIARIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.       A   rosy pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.                but scarcely tangible!
                                                                                                                                            Gelatinous;
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     A scarcely perceptible fringe of delicately hair-like, jointed
                                                                                                                                  threads (<U+FB01>laments),  parasitic on other algae.    Filaments slightly tufted, or
                                                                                                                                  growing close together; straight; compressed; unbranched;       swollen here and
                                                                                                                                  there; tubular; containing rows of minute colour-cells, set as if radiating from
                                                                                                                                  the centre (a microscopic object).
                                                                                                                          Ileasurement.    From A; to      of an inch long.
                                                                                                                                                                   1‘;       From      to    colour-cells in width;
                                                                                                                                                                          -~
                                                                                                                                                                                                       2        3
                                                                                                                                  these forming (with the intervals) a tesselated line across (see Figure).
                                                                                                                          Fruct:/ication. As in the preceding; only with two zoospores to each cell.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Appin. Filey, &c. On Zostera marina, and various small algae near low
                                                                                                                                  water mark.    Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                              Fig.     349.              BANGIA CERAMICOLA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A purplish rose colour.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Gclatinous; soft.
                                                                                                                          Character       Frond. A delicate fringe of <U+FB01>ne, hair-like, jointed threads (filaments)
                                                                                                                                         of
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                  parasitic on other algae. Filaments tufted or growing close together; unbranched;
                                                                                                                                  their joints once or twice as long as broad; slightly contracted at the
                                                                                                                                  partition-lines (dissepimrmts);   marked    with several slender, upright lines
                                                                                                                                  (internal colour-cells showing through), which at maturity run together                                (a
                                                                                                                                  microscopic object).
                                                                                                                          Zlfeasuremcnt. About an inch long.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of                       the line-like colour-cells in the
                                                                                                                                 joints; which cells then run tbgether, and at                    last form a globular mass, that
                                                                                                                                  bursts through the cell-wall, leaving the cell                  empty.
                                                                                                                          Habz-tat. Appin.    Largs, &c. On the smaller algae                     in tide-pools.
                                                                                                                                        Unlike other Bangias in structure.                 Moreover,   much longer        than B. ciliaris.
                                                                                                                                                   Fig.    350.            BANGIA ELEGANS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Rosy pink.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Soft, but scarcely tangible.
                                                                                                                          Cka/racter of Frond.    A delicate fringe of <U+FB01>ne, hair-like, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments)
                                                                                                                                  parasitic on other algae. Filaments tufted, or growing close together; repeatedly
                                                                                                                                  forked;   the angles of branching     (axils) rounded and very wide; tubular;
                                                                                                                                  containing narrow, cylindrical colour-cells, which at maturity run together                            (a
                                                                                                                                  microscopic object).
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          <U+FB02>fcasurement.    From T1; to             1‘;   of an inch long
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.          Minute   seeds     (zoosyaores)   formed of the colour-cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                    which     cells then    run      together    into diamond-shaped masses, and at last drop
                                                                                                                             ~
                                                                                                                                    out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.       Strangford Lough.               Parasitic on the smaller      algae.       Very rare.
                                                                                                                                         This plant    also di<U+FB01>ers entirely             in structure  from      true    Bcmgias, and   will
                                                                                                                                       probably    one day be removed to            a   separate genus.

                                                                                                                                                                    PLATE   LXXV.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.    351.         RIVULARIA PLICATA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Smooth; <U+FB02>eshy; slimy.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Small, rounded, but irregular lumps; several growing together
                                                                                                                                   in a mass; formed of closely-packed      threads ( <U+FB01>laments)   radiating from a
                                                                                                                                   centre.   At <U+FB01>rst solid; afterwards hollow and bursting.
                                                                                                                          Internal Filaments.     Tubular; containing very narrow, cylindrical colour-cells, which
                                                                                                                                   show through, with division-lines;   not branched, but lying against each other
                                                                                                                                   as if they were; a globular cell at the bottom of each (a microscopic object).
                                                                                                                                                                                                               -
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.    The patches inde<U+FB01>nite; each frond from       ,1‘;
                                                                                                                                                                                          to    an inch wide.
                                                                                                                                                                                                 §
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Minute seeds (zoospores)      formed of the colour-cells  in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                   which cells then separate from each other and drop out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts here and there. On rocks near high-water mark.                Not un
                                                                                                                                   common.
                                                                                                                                            Duller, darker coloured, and smaller than R. nitida.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                             Fig. 352.              RIVULARIA ATRA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    Glossy black.
                                                                                                                          Substance.    Hard; <U+FB02>eshy; smooth.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Very minute, bead- or drop-like lumps; scattered, not massed
                                                                                                                                  together;  formed of densely-packed   threads (<U+FB01>laments) radiating outwards.
                                                                                                                                  Always solid;
                                                                                                                          Internal Filaments.     Tubular; containing cylindrical colour-cells of various lengths,
                                                                                                                                  which show through, with division-lines;   not branched, but lying against each
                                                                                                                                  other as if  they were;    globular cell at the bottom of each
                                                                                                                                                                a                                      microscopic
                                                                                                                                                                                                      (a
                                                                                                                                  object.)            -                                                      _
                                                                                                                          Measurement.     Scarcely ever as large as   sweet~pea seed; generally smaller.
                                                                                                                                                                        a
                                                                                                                          Ihwtification.   As in the preceding.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Our coasts generally.        On rocks, stones, and algae between tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                  Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.         353.       RIVULARIA NITIDA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A shining deep green; sometimes verdigris when dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Leathery, but gelatinous; slippery feeling.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Irregularly round, more or less distorted balls; several often
                                                                                                                                  rising together from      a lumpy patch; formed of threads (<U+FB01>laments) radiating
                                                                                                                                  from      centre; the inner ones loosely, the outer closely packed.     When young
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                       a
                                                                                                                                  compressed and <U+FB01>lled with gelatine; when old, hollow and distended.
                                                                                                                          Infernal Filaments.      Tubular; containing narrow cylindrical colour-cells, which show
                                                                                                                                  through, with division-lines;     not branched, but lying against each other as
                                                                                                                                 if   they were;  a   globular cell at the bottom of each       microscopic object).
                                                                                                                                                                                                (a
                                                                                                                          Measurement.       From  ~}, an inch to an inch across.
                                                                                                                          Fructijication.    As before.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Southern shores of England.             Isle of Man.    South and west of Ireland.
                                                                                                                                  On rocks at half-tide level.      Plentiful where it  occurs.
