                                                                                                                                       Fig.     354.       SOHIZOSIPHON VVARHENIZE.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Subslanoe.   Soft; <U+FB02>eshy; slimy.          -
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.    Roundish, irregularly-spreading    lumps, running together, and
                                                                                                                                 forming a glazy crust upon rocks; formed of closely-packed threads (<U+FB01>laments)
                                                                                                                                 radiating from a centre.
                                                                                                                          Internal Filaments. Tubular; containing cylindrical colour-cells, which show through;
                                                                                                                                 set in wide transparent    sheaths, composed of innumerable     upright, hair-like
                                                                                                                                 gelatinous shreds; so closely set as to look entire, all but the tips.  A nearly
                                                                                                                                 globose cell at the bottom of each (a microscopic object).
                                                                                                                          Measurament.   The patches spreading inde<U+FB01>nitely.
                                                                                                                          Frudti<U+FB01>aation. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the coloured cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                  whichcells then separate from each other and drop out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Coast of Devonshire.     On rocks at high-water mark; chie<U+FB02>y in places ex
                                                                                                                                 posed to the drip of fresh water.                                    -
                                                                                                                                       Fig.     355.        SOHIZOTHRIX ORESVVELLII.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.  The tuft greenish-olive; the threads which compose it, yellowish-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.  The tufts soft; spongy; the threads which compose it rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.   Dense, cushion-like  tufts, spreading on the surface of rocks in
                                                                                                                                 round or oval patches; composed of very slender threads (<U+FB01>laments) collected
                                                                                                                                 into branching bundles.     Filaments curved, interlaced, branched in a forked
                                                                                                                                    manner    (a microscopic       object).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.        The patches several inches across.
                                                                                                                          Fruotf<U+FB01>cation.   Not ascertained.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.    On sandstone rocks near high-water             mark; exposed to the drip of fresh water.
                                                                                                                                     Fig.      356.       OALOTHRIX CONFERVIOOLA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      A   <U+FB01>ne, deep,   metallic    green;    re<U+FB02>ecting   prismatic   colours   under water.
                                                                                                                          Substance.      Rigid for so tiny a plant.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froml.       Minute, starry tufts of threads (filaments) only a few in each;
                                                                                                                                   scattered over the fronds of other alga, and often covering them altogether.
                                                                                                                                   Filaments tubular; containing very narrow, cylindrical colour-cells, which show
                                                                                                                                   through, with division-lines.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.       Never more than 1- inch high; often less.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>-cation.     As in Schizosiphon and Rivularia.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     Our   coasts generally.   On small algae between tide-marks.    Abundant in
                                                                                                                                    the autumn.                                                                                -
                                                                                                                                        This charming little parasite, instead of dis<U+FB01>guring the plant on which it
                                                                                                                                     grows, often makes it :1 good deal handsorner than it was before. For instance,
                                                                                                                                     it is s ecially fond of the pale, sickly-looking Ceram-ium rubrum, which grows
                                                                                                                                     in high-water pools, and this it adorns with a fringe of dark green. Some
                                                                                                                                     unusual appearances are <U+FB01>gured in the outer magni<U+FB01>ed form on the Plate.
                                                                                                                                     They are not understood.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          76

                                                                                                                                                                  PLATE       LXXVI.
                                                                                                                                           Fig.     357.    CALOTHRIX PANNOSA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Dark green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.       Rigid;   wiry.
                                                                                                                          Cluzractor of Fro-nd.   Long, blunt, very much curled and twisted threads
                                                                                                                                  (<U+FB01>laments) densely interwoven    into compressed tufts, or a sort of
                                                                                                                                 honeycombed layer on rocks.      Filaments tubular; containing narrow,
                                                                                                                                 cylindrical colour-cells, which show through, with division-lines.
                                                                                                                          Mcaslzrement.       The <U+FB01>laments         1;   an inch long;         the larger   spreading.

                                                                                                                                    high-water mark.   Rarely observed.

                                                                                                                                           Fig.     358.        LYNGBYA MAJUSCULA.

                                                                                                                          Substance.        Crisp; rigid;       glutinous.
                                                                                                                          Character of Froml.    Large tuits or .bundles of long, very thick, curling,
                                                                                                                                 twisted threads (<U+FB01>laments) issuing from interwoven layers of the same.
                                                                                                                                 Filaments not branched, but lying together as if they were; tubular;
                                                                                                                                 containing very narrow, cylindrical, dull-green colour-cells, which show
                                                                                                                                     through; their division-lines           obscure.

                                                                                                                                                            1                                                        spreading.
                                                                                                                          Fructz<U+FB01>cation.       As in    Calothria:, &c.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.        Our coasts generally. On mud or sand-covered rocks at and below
                                                                                                                                     half-tide level; also thrown up after storms. Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                       By far the largest of British I/jngbyas,         and like tufts of curling human hair,
                                                                                                                                     were it not for the mermaidy colour.

                                                                                                                                               Fig.    359.          LYNGBYA FLAOOA.

                                                                                                                                    there a few root-like branchlets.    Filaments very slender; <U+FB01>ner than

                                                                                                                                    matter     (endochrozne)       which   afterwardscontracts into a dark spot in
                                                                                                                                    the centre.

                                                                                                                                   the joints, collected into a, round central               mass (sporidium),          which    in
                                                                                                                                    due time bursts         out.

                                                                                                                                                                   PLATE     LXXVIII.
                                                                                                                                             Fig.     367.       LYNGBYA FERRUGINEA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     A dull verdigris-green, changing to rust-colour, but resuming the green,
                                                                                                                                   when dry.
                                                                                                                           Substance.     Soft; woolly when dry.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Excessively slender threads (<U+FB01>laments) closely matted together;
                                                                                                                                   forming a layer at the bottom of mud-bottomed          pools.    Filaments bent in
                                                                                                                                   various curves, but not twisted;       unbranched;   tubular; containing narrow,
                                                                                                                                   cylindrical colour-cells, which show through; with tolerably clear division-lines.
                                                                                                                          llleasurement.     Filaments from Q; to 1 inch high; the larger spreading for several
                                                                                                                                   inches.                                  -
                                                                                                                          F/ructi<U+FB01>eation.     Minute   seeds (zoospores) formed  of the colour-cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                   which cells then separate from each other, and at last drop out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Appin, and elsewhere. Filey, on the rocks leading to the bridge.                 In
                                                                                                                                   small mud-bottomed pools near high-water mark.          Not uncommon.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.      368.       LYNGBYA CARMICHZELII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A bright grass-green.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.     Soft.                                    -
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.      Very long, wavy, strongly curled, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                  <U+FB01>xed at base, but forming extensive, closely-entangled,     <U+FB01>eecy layers; <U+FB02>oating
                                                                                                                                  freely under water.
                                                                                                                          Joints. Very short; scarcely half as long as broad; <U+FB01>lled with dense green colouring
                                                                                                                                  matter (endochrome), which afterwards contracts into a dark spot in the centre.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      Almost inde<U+FB01>nite.     On Fucus vesiculosus, upwards of 1 foot.       On
                                                                                                                           -      rocks, covering a space of 20 or 30 yards.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>eation.     Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                  collectedinto a round central mass (sporidium), which in due time bursts out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. South and west coasts of England. \Vest of Scotland.           Ireland generally.

                                                                                                                                                Fig.    369.        LYNGBYA SPECIOSA.

                                                                                                                                         Fig.     370.     LYNGBYA CUTLERIZE.
                                                                                                                           Colour.    A brilliant light grass-green.
                                                                                                                           Substance.     Very soft and delicate.
                                                                                                                          Character 0/'1-“ronll.    Excessively slender, gently waved, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments);
                                                                                                                                   unbranched;    <U+FB01>xed at base, but forming <U+FB02>eecy layers; <U+FB02>oating      freely under

                                                                                                                                   which afterwards contracts into a round spot in the centre.
                                                                                                                          Jlleasurement.     From     to 1 inch long.
                                                                                                                          Fructl<U+FB01>cation.     Minute seeds (zoosporcs) formed of the colouring matter in the joints,
                                                                                                                                   collected into a round central mass (sporidium), which in due time bursts out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. In estuaries.       Exmouth, Miss Cutler. But the plant should be looked for
                                                                                                                                   further.
                                                                                                                                                         Now Hormotrichum    Cut-leriaa.
                                                                                                                                  Fig.    371.     MICROCOLEUS ANGUIFORMIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    A dull, dark green.
                                                                                                                                         Soft; gelatinous.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       Dense layers of small, snake-like tubes, tapering at their ends,
                                                                                                                                  widening upwards;      open at the tops; forming patches on mud.      Tubes <U+FB01>lled
                                                                                                                                  (when fully developed) with numbers of very minute, stiff, straight threads
                                                                                                                                  (<U+FB01>laments); whose tips issue from the open tops, and may be observed (under
                                                                                                                                  a microscope) to wave backwards and forwards (oscillate).
                                                                                                                          Measurement.      The patches about an inch long.
                                                                                                                          Frucli<U+FB01>cation.     Minute seeds (zooepores) formed of the colour-cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                  which cells then separate, and in due time drop out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Coast of Wales.         West of Scotland.    Pools of brackish water near the
                                                                                                                                  shore.
                                                                                                                                           372.     OSCILLATORIA LITTORALIS.
                                                                                                                           Colour.    The mass verdigris-green;   dried <U+FB01>laments deep green.
                                                                                                                           Substance.     The mass slimy; <U+FB01>laments elastic; when dry, mernbranaceous; scarcely
                                                                                                                                   adhering to paper.
                                                                                                                           Character of Frond.      A thin layer of slender, straight, or slightly-curved threads
                                                                                                                                   (<U+FB01>laments); generally twisted into bundles.      Filaments apt to break into
                                                                                                                                   needle-like fragments; unbranched; tubular; containing very narrow cylindrical
                                                                                                                                   colour-cells, which show through; their division-lines conspicuous, at intervals
                                                                                                                                   of about one-third the width of the <U+FB01>lament.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.      Inde<U+FB01>nite.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Fruct;/ication. Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colour-cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                   which cells at last separate from each other and drop out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Appin. In pools along the muddy sea-shore, <U+FB02>ooded by spring tides.
                                                                                                                                    The <U+FB01>laments of this genus may be observed (under the microscope) wavin
                                                                                                                                  to and fro (oscillating) as if possessed of animal life. For this purpose a morsz<U+FB01>
                                                                                                                                  should be placed in a glass with a few drops of water.         The reason of this
                                                                                                                                  curious fact is not known.

                                                                                                                                                                    PLATE   LXXIX.
                                                                                                                                            Fig.    373.       OSCILLATORIA SPIRALIS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.   The layer greenish-black, or verdigris; glossy; dried <U+FB01>laments the same.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   The layer sometimes leathery, sometimes membranaceous; scarcely gela
                                                                                                                                 tinous; <U+FB01>laments rigid.
                                                                                                                          Character Qf Frond.    A more or less thin layer of short, slender, jointed threads
                                                                                                                                 (<U+FB01>laments), sti<U+FB01>ly cuzled and twisted; turned in all directions; densely inter
                                                                                                                                 woven.   Filaments apt to break into short fragments;      unbranched; tubular;
                                                                                                                                 containing narrow, cylindrical colour-cells, which show through, with division
                                                                                                                                  lines.
                                                                                                                          lleasurement.         The larger layers   sometimes   several feet in extent.   Filaments about
                                                                                                                                    -51;; of an inch   long!
                                                                                                                          Fructt<U+FB01>cation.        Minute seeds (zoospores) formed of the colour-cells in the <U+FB01>laments;
                                                                                                                                    which     cells at last separate from each other and fall out.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.         Our coasts generally.    On rocks above and between tide-marks;  often left
                                                                                                                                    dry.
                                                                                                                                       The waving to-and-fro (oscillating)        movement of Oscillatoria   <U+FB01>laments   has
                                                                                                                                     been mentioned under Fig. 372.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                             Fig.   374.       SPIRULINA TENUISSIMA.
                                                                                                                           Colour.    Rich metallic, or verdigris-green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.     The layer very gelatinous; slimy.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.       A thin <U+FB01>lm of excessively slender, wavy, densely-twisted threads
                                                                                                                                   (<U+FB01>laments), lying nearly parallel.     Filaments unbranched; tubular; contain
                                                                                                                                   ing bright green colour-cells, which show through; their division-lines close,
                                                                                                                                   and more or less distinct.
                                                                                                                          llfcaeurement.    The layer § of an inch or more across.
                                                                                                                          Fructl<U+FB01>cation. As above, in Oscillatoria.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. On decaying algae, sticks, &c. in brackish pools near Menai Bridge.
                                                                                                                                   Pool near Dolgelly. Aberdeen.
                                                                                                                                       The <U+FB01>laments of Spirulina, like those of Oscillatoria and Microcolezw, have,
                                                                                                                                     when alive and under water, the to-and-fro movement called oscillation, and in
                                                                                                                                     Spirulina the movement is particularly vivid.

                                                                                                                                      APPENDIX                          -OF NEW SPECIES
                                                                                                                          DISCOVERED                  SINCE    THE PUBLICATION OF THE “PHYCOLOGIA
                                                                                                                                                                  BRITANNICA.”
                                                                                                                                                              O   LIVE           G R O U P.
                                                                                                                                                               FAMILY    I.      FUCACEE.
                                                                                                                                                                  FUCODIUM        ANCEPS.
                                                                                                                          Colour.    When fresh, olive green.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Tough and leathery.
                                                                                                                          Character    of   From/l.    Compressed, slender, branched.       Branchlets      forked (dichotomous).
                                                                                                                          ilfeaeurement.   Four or 5 inches long.
                                                                                                                          Air-vessels. None observed.

Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                  pod-like forks at the tips of the branchlets.
                                                                                                                           Habitat.    Only found as yet on a rock at Kilkee, Co. Clare.
                                                                                                                                        This was Dr. Harvey's last discovery in 1863, of which the reader must for
                                                                                                                                      the present accept an unscienti<U+FB01>c description.     The long, narrow, pod-like
                                                                                                                                      receptacles standing upright in pairs at the ends of the branchlets, distinguish
                                                                                                                                      this Fucodium from all the others.
                                                                                                                                                        FAMILY    II.    SPOROCHNACEJE.
                                                                                                                                                              DESMARESTIA         DRESNAII.
                                                                                                                          Colour.      Pale brown, becoming       a pleasant     olive-green    when     dry.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Firmly mcmbranaceous;            somewhat horny when fresh;              never becoming very
                                                                                                                                 soft.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Flat, leaf-like, with an evident but thin midrib throughout,
                                                                                                                                 and side veins; margins slightly indented.      When perfect, oppositely branched
                                                                                                                                 (if the phrase be allowed) with leaf-like fronds of the same chazacter: the whole
                                                                                                                                 plant consisting of leafy formations, springing from each other.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.   Specimen in Trinity College Herbarium (Dublin), 10 inches long by
                                                                                                                                 2 wide.  But Mr. Sawers describes others as 18 inches long, breadth 3.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB02>cation. Not ascertained.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Moville Bay, Co. Donegal,             1853.    Mr. IV.      Sawers.
                                                                                                                                         By Agardh, and also by Dr.             this
                                                                                                                                                                                  plant is considered as only an ex
                                                                                                                                                                      Harvey, ut no
                                                                                                                                      travagantly wide form of D. ligulata;       one who has not seen intermediate
                                                                                                                                      specimens can easily believe this. Yet, in   the tapering to both ends of the
                                                                                                                                      so-called branches of the common forms of   D. ligulata, a tendency to leaf-like
                                                                                                                                       formation may be observed; the branchlets especially, resembling small ribless
                                                                                                                                      leaves. On the other hand, the “obscure midrib towards the base" of D. ligulata
                                                                                                                                       indicates an inclination to that formation also. An     one interested in the
                                                                                                                                       subject will <U+FB01>nd the growth of Desmarestia described in Dr. Harvey's Nereis
                                                                                                                                       Boreali-Americana,  vol. i. p. 77.

                                                                                                                                      (<U+FB01>g‘ 54) by its decidedly solid substance.      A touch ascertains this at once.
                                                                                                                                      And its tuber-like character sul<U+FB01>ciently distinguishes     from L. Berkeleyi (<U+FB01>g.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    it
                                                                                                                                             The more advanced student, who is disposed to make durch-schnitts of
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                      59).
                                                                                                                                      the two tuberous forms, will observe that the threads which compose the outer
                                                                                                                                      coat (periphery) of L. tuberifm-n<is are short and straight; whereas those of L.
                                                                                                                                      crispa. are very distinctly curled, and are rather longer: nor are they as regu
                                                                                                                                      larly and roundly bead-like in the latter as in the former. Very little difference
                                                                                                                                      is  observable in the spores (which are borne among these outer-coat <U+FB01>laments
                                                                                                                                      at the base).   For scienti<U+FB01>c description and <U+FB01>gure see Natural History Review,
                                                                                                                                      1857, “Proceedings   of Societies,” p. 201.

                                                                                                                                 The Rev. F. W. Hayden, 1862.                                             -
                                                                                                                                        Those sufficiently interested in the E'lax:lzistas to examine them microscopically
                                                                                                                                     will be glad to be told further that the tubercle, whence their tufts arise, is in
                                                                                                                                     all cases composed of branching threads, so closely packed together as to form
                                                                                                                                     a compact mass. And among these branching threads nestle the spores, which
                                                                                                                                     in E. Ila;/dent are at the lower end of the threads, narrow oval in shape (narrow
                                                                                                                                     ob-ovate,  i. e. the reversed egg-shape—the small end upwards), and have an
                                                                                                                                     abrupt     cut-off appearance at top.                                            ~
