                                                                                                                                                         FAMILY      VI. ECTOCARPACEE.
                                                                                                                                                            ECTOCARPUS TESSELATUS.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                              This plant having been alluded to under <U+FB01>g. 95.as raised to the dignity of a
                                                                                                                          species, it is necessary to add here that Dr. Harvey does not allow its claims to
                                                                                                                          any other position than that of a varied form of E. granulosus            (<U+FB01>g. 95); a
                                                                                                                          species very irregular in its habit of growth.    Sometimes it is alternate/y branched
                                                                                                                          throughout, as appears to have been the case in the plant from which the <U+FB01>gure in
                                                                                                                          .E'n-qZish Baton]; was taken, or it is alternately   branched in the larger divisions,
                                                                                                                          and exactly oppositely in the lesser ones, as <U+FB01>gured in the Pb-/cologia     Britannica,
                                                                                                                          or the last branchlets are secund,                1-.
                                                                                                                                                                 e. set along one side of the penultimate    ones,
                                                                                                                                    as
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      -

                                                                                                                                                                  APPENDIX.
                                                                                                                          like the teeth of a comb. And this is the case with the pretty form E. tesselafus,
                                                                                                                          <U+FB01>rst discovered by the Rev. F. W. Hayden, in rock crevices on the rugged surface
                                                                                                                          of Filey Bridge, at the further extremity.       And as this secund branchleting occurs
                                                                                                                          on both     alternately- and oppositely-branched  specimens, it would seem that these
                                                                                                                          varieties of habit are of little importance.
                                                                                                                             The oppositely-branched is commonest on the south coast, and the alternate, or
                                                                                                                          alternate-opposite,    in the north. But they are found c0nvm-seZ-y.     Dr. Cocks fur
                                                                                                                          nished <U+FB01>ne allernato-semmd to his Algarum Fasciculi from Plymouth; and opposite
                                                                                                                          secund,   with occasional double pairs, was gathered off a buoy at Whitby this year
                                                                                                                          (1862).     Filey Bridge a<U+FB01>ords the three varieties.
                                                                                                                             The peculiarities of E. tesselatus appear to be the secund branchlets; a beautiful
                                                                                                                          green-olive    colour, and a richness and closeness of branching quite unknown in the
                                                                                                                          larger forms, which often become straggling and have long portions of their stems
                                                                                                                          naked.     In a collection it will be well to call this plant Ectocarpus granulosus,
                                                                                                                           var. sec-1mdalus—a     name bestowed upon one of the secund forms by Lyngbye; and
                                                                                                                          as Agardh       unites under E. granulosus the oppositely-branched   Iwlus, the collector
                                                                                                                          may, if he pleases, subdivide the three forms by separate titles.  The epithet tesselafuc
                                                                                                                          is equally applicable to all, for it was suggested by the tesselated appearance of the
                                                                                                                          fruit; but this can only be observed under a very good microscope.          The Whitby
                                                                                                                          specimens, before alluded to, were furnished, besides the usual fruit, with globular
                                                                                                                          bodies, having the appearance of spores inclosed in ahyaline cell.    These were seated
                                                                                                                          for the most part on the stems, the tesselated fruit on the branchlets.         It is ad
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          mitted by all, that the fructi<U+FB01>cation of the Ectocarpi is very imperfectly understood;
                                                                                                                          the tesselated formations not having the usual characters of spores.
                                                                                                                                                        RED GROUP.
                                                                                                                                               Fmur VII.          RHODOMELACEJE.
                                                                                                                                                      RYTIPHLEA OXYAOANTHA.
                                                                                                                             A most delicate and lovely form discovered by Miss Turner in Jersey, in 1855,
                                                                                                                          and provisionally    called R. 0.111/ncanf/la by Dr. Harvey.  He is unwilling, however,
                                                                                                                          to subdivide species unnecessarily, and has satis<U+FB01>ed himself that this attractive little
                                                                                                                          plant is but a slender and graceful variety of R3/tiphlwa tIm_yoia7Ps (<U+FB01>g. 101.)     Its
                                                                                                                          general appearance is much less still‘ and formal than that of the usual R. thug
                                                                                                                          oides, for the branchlets, instead of being short, and re-branchleted  with another set
                                                                                                                          shorter still, are longer   and simpler, being rarely re-branchleted  at all.  It seems
                                                                                                                          hard not to allow so interesting a variety a special name, but almost          as much
                                                                                                                          difference may be observed in the stiffer or slenderer forms of Polysiphonia parasiliva
                                                                                                                          as between R. ox]/acantha and the coarser R. thuyoides.
                                                                                                                                  -                 POLYSIPHONIA FGZTIDISSIMA.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             Specimens under     this name having been distributed in Dr. Cocks’ A7-qarum
                                                                                                                          Fasciculi, it is necesssry to mention that Dr. Harvey does not consider it speci<U+FB01>cally
                                                                                                                          distinct from P. <U+FB01>brata (<U+FB01>g. 113).       It is rather purpler in hue; but whether this
                                                                                                                          arises from anything more than its growing on mud in a harbour, where the water
                                                                                                                          cannot be so pure as on a more open sea, seems doubtful.        Its professed habitats are
                                                                                                                          the landing-places on the shore of Mount Edgcumbe, and Torpoint.
                                                                                                                                                                                                           90

                                                                                                                                                                            APPENDIX.
                                                                                                                                                                       DASYA PUNICEA.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Bright     rosy crimson;    fading   to yellow and whitish.
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Soft, and somewhat         gelatinous;   soon decomposing      in fresh water.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     Thread-like (<U+FB01>lamentous); irregularly, much branched; bushy;
                                                                                                                                 the principal branches widely spreading and bearing many short branchlets
                                                                                                                                 on each side.     Stems unjointed; the older ones worn naked and smooth;
                                                                                                                                 the younger,    throughout the plant, closely set with rings (whorls) of very
                                                                                                                                  slender, delicate, soft, jointed branchleteene.  These branchleteens, -} of an
                                                                                                                                 inch long; many times forked; tapering to a point; their joints from 4: to 6
                                                                                                                                 times as long as broad.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.     From 2 to 3 inches long, and as much in the spread of the branches.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation. Of two kinds; external.     1. Clustered spores, in broadly ovate capsules
                                                                                                                                 with a short protruding mouth (urooolate); seated (sessile) on the branchlets.
                                                                                                                                 2. Tetraspores in lauceolate, pointed,  pod-like receptacles (stioliidia); on the
                                                                                                                                    branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitat.  Bognor, October,                1858, Mrs.   Gray.     Brighton,    July   and August, 1859,
                                                                                                                                 Mrs. Merri<U+FB01>eld.
                                                                                                                                        This interesting addition to the list of British Seaweeds resembles Agardh's
                                                                                                                                     Trieste species, D. punicea, so closely, that Dr. Harvey believes it may be the
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                                      same,  although differing in one particular     character; viz. the length of the
                                                                                                                                     joints of the branchleteens.    Those of Agardh’s plant being short; of the
                                                                                                                                     present form, long.
                                                                                                                                                                    DASYA CATTLOVIZE           P
                                                                                                                             A form not yet described, from the fact that only one specimen, and that a barren
                                                                                                                          one, has as yet been found.     This unique treasure was discovered <U+FB02>oating at very
                                                                                                                          low water in St. Aubin's Bay, not far from Elizabeth Castle, Jersey, in August,
                                                                                                                          1858, by Miss Mary Cattlow.      Externally, it bears some likeness to an Australian
                                                                                                                          species, D. Gunniana; but its characters come nearest to those of the Mediterranean
                                                                                                                          species,  D. punicm, above described as having been lately found on the British
                                                                                                                          shores.   Dr. Harvey considers D. Cattloviw more robust, however, and its brancleteens
                                                                                                                          more generally distributed, and is inclined to think it may prove a distinct species.
                                                                                                                             It is mentioned here in the hope that such an announcement may induce other
                                                                                                                          collectors to make diligent search for more specimens.
                                                                                                                                                         FAMIBY       IX.     WRANGELIACEZE.
                                                                                                                                                                 NACCARIA        HYPNOIDES.
                                                                                                                          Colour.        Delicate    rosy-red.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Yery     soft and gelatinous;      adhering   closely   to paper in drying.
                                                                                                                          Character of       F
                                                                                                                                           rond.  Slender; thread-shaped   (<U+FB01>liform); profusely branched; solitary
                                                                                                                                 or tufted.    Stems wide in proportion to the branchlets; once or twice forked;
                                                                                                                                 set with long, wavy, horizontally-spread,  opposite or alternate branches, tapering
                                                                                                                                 gradually upwards, and several times rehranched.       Branches clothed with very
                                                                                                                                 slender-jointed   branchlets; these furnished at every joint with rings (wlzorls)
                                                                                                                                 of minute, bead-like branchleteens, once or twice forked, and forming a little
                                                                                                                                 frill round each joint. Structure of the stem, an internal jointed tube,
                                                                                                                                    91

                                                                                                                                                                         APPENDIX.
                                                                                                                                    covered by a streaked, <U+FB01>brous membrane, which, when fully developed, conceals
                                                                                                                                    it.  The younger branches, or branchlets, therefore, where this coating is
                                                                                                                                    imperfectly grown, appear jointed, the older stems not. A branchlet, with its
                                                                                                                                    bead-like branchleteens fringing the partition lines (dissepiments) of every
                                                                                                                                    joint, is an exquisite microscopic object.
                                                                                                                          llfeasurement.      Two or four inches long, and as much in the spread of the branches.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB02>cation.       Only one kind known.    Tufts of naked s72or<'s formed in the middle
                                                                                                                                  part of the branchlets, swelling them out; attached to the w/zorled branchleteens.
                                                                                                                          Habitm‘.    S. Catherine’s  Bay, Jersey: Miss Turner and Mr. Girdlestone.       Exmouth:
                                                                                                                                  Mrs. Gulson.
                                                                                                                                        It will be seen by a reference back to N. 'W1'ggiihow materially these species
                                                                                                                                     di<U+FB02>'er in internal structure, which we call attention to because, without reference
                                                                                                                                     to it, specimens of the two are often confounded.
                                                                                                                                                        FAMILY    XIV.      SQUAMARIE /E.
                                                                                                                                                                  CRUORIA PELLITA.
                                                                                                                                                              ‘
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Dingy red.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Tough, but rather <U+FB02>eshy feeling.
                                                                                                                          Characier Q/'Fron1l.   A scab-like incrustation spreading on the surface of rocks;
                                                                                                                                 composed of minute densely-packed, upright, jointed threads (<U+FB01>laments), set in
                                                                                                                                 gelatine.  Filaments robust at the base; tapering upwards; in tufted bundles
                                                                                                                                 below; such of them as elongate, spreading     upwards in a repeatedly forked
                                                                                                                                    manner.
                                                                                                                          Ilfeasurevment. The patches inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                          Fructz<U+FB01>catz-on.  Only one kind known.   Telrmsjzores oblong, divided by zones; clavate;
                                                                                                                                  forming a branch of one of the <U+FB01>laments.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Sound of         J
                                                                                                                                                 ura: Rev. C. P. Miles.    Cumbrae:   on mussel shells (dredged),
                                                                                                                                  and on Lmninaria stems; Mr. Hennedy.           Miltown Malbay: Dr. Harvey.
                                                                                                                                  Probably in many other places.    On rocks between tide-marks.
                                                                                                                                          The Cruoria pellita of <U+FB01>g. 227 has been transferred to another genus, and
                                                                                                                                     is    now ‘Petrocelis cruenta. This change is owing to the position and character
                                                                                                                                     of    the fruit.   In Petrocelis (which, like Cruoria, is an incrustation composed
                                                                                                                                     of   jointed threads) the tetraspores are formed in the (then) swollen centre cell
                                                                                                                                     of the threads themselves.   In true Cruor-ia they are borne, as above described,
                                                                                                                                     on the threads of which the frond is composed: in fact, by the transformation
                                                                                                                                     of a branch into fruit. Scienti<U+FB01>c accounts of the Cruorias, accompanied by
                                                                                                                                     plates, were published  in the 1\"atu1'al History Review, 1857, “Proceedings of
                                                                                                                                     Societies," p. 201.
                                                                                                                                                              CRUORIA ADHZERENS.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Colour.   Purplish or discolouring olive.
                                                                                                                          Substance.   Tough, but rather <U+FB02>eshy-feeling.
                                                                                                                          Character of Frond.     A scab-like incrustation spreading on rocks and laminaria
                                                                                                                                 stems; composed of minute densely-packed, upright, jointed threads (<U+FB01>lammzls),
                                                                                                                                 set in gelatine.  Filaments tapering to both ends; many of them quite simple;
                                                                                                                                    a few once or twice     forked   upwards.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.         The patches inde<U+FB01>nite.
                                                                                                                                                                                                               92

                                                                                                                                                                       APPENDIX.
                                                                                                                          Fructi<U+FB01>cation.      Not clearly ascertained.    Professor  Agardh indeed says it 'bears
                                                                                                                                    tetraspores, but these have not been found in Great Britain.       Dr. Walker
                                                                                                                                    Arnott assures us after patient study of the two species, that he has never
                                                                                                                                    seen a single specimen of C. adluereas in tetrasporic fruit. This species, how
                                                                                                                                    ever, bears very commonly certain green spore-like bodies or sacs, which look
                                                                                                                                    at <U+FB01>rst sight like fructi<U+FB01>cation, but on examination cannot be ascertained to
                                                                                                                                    he such.    It is remarkable that these sacs are not found on C. pcllita, on
                                                                                                                                    which the tetrasporic fruit is not uncommon, and Dr. Arnott inclines to the
                                                                                                                                    belief that C. adhwrens is merely a barren form of C’. pellita.
                                                                                                                          Habitat. Kilereggan. Opposite Gourqck: Professor Walker Arnott.   Aberdeen: Dr.
                                                                                                                                 Dickie. Penzance: Mr. Rails. Kilkee, 1844, Cushendall, Co. Antrim, 1850;
                                                                                                                                 Dr. Harvey.   And probably in many other places.  On rocks between tide
                                                                                                                                    marks.
                                                                                                                                       Thesc odd incrustations form red stains on rocks and stones, as if blood had
                                                                                                                                     been spilt there, and can only be removed by a knife; and, of course, can
                                                                                                                                     only be understood by examination under the microscope.
                                                                                                                                                          ACTINOCOCOUS              HENNEDYI.
                                                                                                                          Colour.     Deep red.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-05 14:05 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015061870526
                                                                                                                          Substance.        Toughish, but rather gelatinous.
                                                                                                                          Character   Q/' Frond.     An incrustation found on the Laminaria stems; composed of
                                                                                                                                 minute,    closely-packed,  upright-jointed bead-like threads (<U+FB01>laments), set in
                                                                                                                                 gelatine.    Filaments tapering upwards; bead-like; sometimes simple, but fre
                                                                                                                                 quently once or twice branched.
                                                                                                                          Measurement.         Inde<U+FB01>nite in outline.
                                                                                                                          Fructf<U+FB01>cation.     Only one kind known.      Large tetraspores, formed by degrees in
                                                                                                                                    nearly all the joints of the threads, transforming; them into “necklace-like
                                                                                                                                    strings of deep red beads.”  Each tetraspore divided cross-wise (eruciate).
                                                                                                                          Habitat.     On an old root of Laminaria digitata             at Cumbzaz:   Mr. Roger Heunedy,
                                                                                                                                    1852.
                                                                                                                                        A beautiful microscopic object. For a scienti<U+FB01>c account and <U+FB01>gure of this
                                                                                                                                     plant and others, see Natural History Review for 1857, “Proceedings of
                                                                                                                                     Societies," p. 201.
